title: As Trump Crows Over Ending a Conflict, India’s Leaders Feel Betrayed
content: President Trump’s repeated descriptions of U.S. mediation efforts between India and Pakistan have hit sore spots in Indian politics.
resumen: President Trump announced a cease-fire after a military conflict between India and Pakistan. Trump claimed he offered to increase trade with India and Pakistan if they ceased hostilities, and threatened to halt it if they did not, which India contradicted. An official in India’s foreign ministry said that the issue of trade did not come up in any of the discussions. India is concerned about how the Indian public will view their conduct of India’s military effort. The U.S. has long been a force in cooling flare-ups in this part of the world. India expected that such intervention from a partner it was growing to trust would happen quietly and on favorable terms. The Indian government refused to publicly acknowledge the American role, insisting that the deal had been reached directly with Pakistan. Mr. Trump’s overall U.S. messaging — in which Mr. Trump also spoke of India and Pakistan on equal terms and offered to mediate issues that India considers strictly bilateral — was seen as leaving India’s political leaders vulnerable. Analysts aligned with the right-wing base of Prime Minister Narendra Modi questioned India’s shift toward closer U.S. relations, describing Mr. Trump’s comments as a betrayal. Mr. Trump held back military aid to Pakistan during his first administration. In the first months of his second term, the relationship between New Delhi and Washington appeared to be only deepening, with India purchasing billions of dollars of American military equipment. After the deadly terrorist attack last month that sent tensions soaring between India and Pakistan, Mr. Trump was among the first world leaders to call Mr. Modi and offer support. Mr. Trump offered gracious words for both sides in announcing the cease-fire. He made no mention of how the confrontation had started with a terrorist attack that killed 26 civilians in Indian-controlled Kashmir. The president spoke of future negotiations on the competing claims by India and Pakistan over the Kashmir region. On Tuesday in Saudi Arabia, Mr. Trump said that both countries had very “powerful” and “strong” leaders, and that they might now “go out and have a nice dinner together.” Nirupama Menon Rao, a former Indian ambassador to Washington, said that the American approach had complicated India’s decades of efforts to be viewed independently, not through the lens of conflict with Pakistan. India has reoriented its foreign policy to position itself as the United States’ key partner in the region, increasingly willing to play the role of counterweight to China. Vice President JD Vance told Fox News that the escalating conflict was “fundamentally none of our business.” In the following days, Mr. Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio became the anchors of an urgent diplomatic effort to end the fighting. Alarm had grown after India struck an airfield within 15 miles of both the Pakistani military headquarters and the unit that oversees and protects the country’s nuclear arsenal. A senior Indian official said that India, before hitting Pakistan, had been in communication with the Trump administration about its intent to do so, and that it had briefed Mr. Trump’s advisers after the initial strikes. Mr. Vance called Mr. Modi to share the U.S. concern about “a high probability of a dramatic escalation of violence.” Mr. Modi listened, but India made its own decision to end the fighting, the official said, after another night of clashes in which Indian forces struck several Pakistani bases. Pakistan requested a direct call to discuss arrangements for a cease-fire. Indrani Bagchi, a New Delhi-based foreign policy analyst, said that the U.S. and China may be strategic rivals everywhere, but they come together in Pakistan.

title: Idaho farmers (and our small health products company) will struggle even with Trump’s 30% tariff rate (Opinion)
content: President Donald Trump’s newly reduced China tariff will still wipe out the investments made in our small family business and kill our manufacturing plant, here in Boise.
resumen:
According to the Idaho Farm Bureau, 2023 Census data showed that through the first nine months Idaho exported $288 million worth of ag products to Canada; $186 million to Mexico, $83 million to China and $51 million to Japan.

President Donald Trump’s China tariff will still wipe out the investments made in a small family business and kill their manufacturing plant in Boise.

The family business produces health products, from protein or energy powders to supplements with vitamins and custom ingredients. They exported to Poland, Brazil, Thailand and Australia. They paid above-average wages to the four employees they depend on.

A Chinese company requested products from them. Trump’s ever-changing tariffs killed the idea — 145% tariff coming in, 125% tariff when exported.

Idaho ranks third in the United States in dairy production and grows two-thirds of sweet corn seed worldwide, along with potatoes, wheat — 50% of which is exported — onions, food trout and barley.

USDA data reported by the Idaho Farm Bureau Federation show that from 2016 to 2019, Idaho’s agricultural exports grew each year.

In 2018, Trump added tariffs for China, and China reduced its purchases of American soybeans, corn, and pork. Many farmers lost their land, while others received some of the $23 billion in subsidies that the first Trump administration doled out.

Trump has eased many tariffs from most countries, including Mexico and Canada, for 90 days. Yet he initially increased tariffs on most Chinese products, causing China to retaliate. Negotiations resulted in both countries reducing their escallation tariffs to 30% and 10% respectively.

In 2022 China accounted for 8% of Idaho’s agricultural exports, or $231.2 million. Our biggest ag export to China is whey from Idaho’s dairy farms.

“The Farm Bureau supports the goals of security and ensuring fair trade, but farmers and rural communities often bear the brunt of tariffs and tariff retaliation,” said Sean Ellis, spokesman for the Idaho Farm Bureau Federation.

President Trump has offered varying justifications for imposing tariffs on some 90 countries around the world, now “paused,” but his basic explanation is that they will “bring manufacturing back home.”

The author has been calling and writing their Idaho members of Congress: Senators Jim Risch and Mike Crapo, and Congressman Mike Simpson, all Republicans.

India y Pakistán, ambos con armas nucleares, han evitado la guerra directa a pesar de las tensiones. La disuasión nuclear ha influido en su comportamiento, pero de manera diferente.

Pakistán, con menos recursos, ha dependido de armas nucleares de corto alcance y una estrategia de "primer uso" para contrarrestar la superioridad convencional de India. Esto aumenta el riesgo de escalada nuclear.

India, con una postura de "no primer uso", se enfoca en una disuasión creíble de represalia, desarrollando un arsenal nuclear más grande y diverso, incluyendo misiles balísticos intercontinentales y una tríada nuclear.

Las crisis de Kargil en 1999 y los ataques de Mumbai en 2008 demostraron la estabilidad de la disuasión nuclear, pero también revelaron riesgos. La falta de comunicación y la posibilidad de errores de cálculo podrían llevar a una escalada.

content: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent insists the US-China talks are part of a broader strategy of “economic decoupling for strategic necessities.” He emphasized that “generalized decoupling” is not US ...
resumen:
A brief easing of tariffs between the US and China has set off a burst of transpacific trade activity, but deeper tensions and long-term supply chain disruptions continue to cloud the outlook.

A 90-day truce in the ongoing US-China trade war has sparked a rush to move goods across the Pacific, with businesses scrambling to take advantage of temporarily lowered tariffs.

President Donald Trump reduced US duties on Chinese imports from 145% to 30%. China slashed its tariffs on American goods from 125% to 10%.

Container carriers like CMA CGM and Hapag-Lloyd reportedly praised the pause and expect to see a spike in bookings.

David Roche, president of financial analysis firm Quantum Strategy in Singapore, said that at 30%, something gets shipped—but far less than when we were at 8% before Trump took office. He noted that a modest uptick in container traffic might soon appear in Port of Los Angeles bookings.

April inflation data showed year-over-year inflation cooled slightly to 2.3%—just under the 2.4% forecast—prices still rose 0.2% month-over-month. Core inflation held steady at 2.8%.

Fitch Ratings downgraded its 2025 global GDP forecast to 1.9%.

Fitch’s chief economist, Brian Coulton, said the latest 90-day pause brings the US effective tariff rate down from 23% to 13%, it’s still far above the 2.3% level seen in 2024.

Coulton said the trade war, “which is already having a tangible economic impact, is not over,” citing remaining 10% baseline tariffs and industry-specific levies still in force.

US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent insists the US-China talks are part of a broader strategy of “economic decoupling for strategic necessities.”

China remains the US’s most heavily tariffed trading partner. According to Fitch, the current ETR for Chinese imports stands at 31.8%.

Certain electronics like smartphones and computers were excluded from the most recent round of tariffs.

Analysts for Singapore-based UOB Group struck a more optimistic tone following the pause in US-China trade tensions, forecasting a near-term economic boost for China as exporters rush to front-load production and shipments to the US during the window.

UOB analysts said they see some upside potential to their 2025 growth forecast for China of 4.3%.

UOB expects China to continue focusing on domestic resilience and export diversification.

title: Trump order envisions major drug price negotiations, savings
content: The Legislature and Gov. Maura Healey last year enacted a pair of new health policy laws, including one aimed at reining in prescription drug costs.
resumen:
President Donald Trump said the executive order he signed Monday morning will reduce prescription drug prices by 30% to 80% "almost immediately."

The U.S. accounts for 5% of the world's population but about 75% of the world's pharmaceutical profits.

The executive order declares that Americans must have access to "the most-favored-nation price" for prescription drugs and biologics. That would mean that the U.S. would pay the same price as whichever nation pays the lowest price for a drug.

The U.S. Trade Representative and the U.S. Department of Commerce are directed to take "all necessary and appropriate action" against unreasonable and discriminatory policies in foreign countries that suppress drug prices abroad.

U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Robert Kennedy Jr. is directed to facilitate direct-to-consumer sales at "most-favored-nation" prices for drugs deemed appropriate.

Within 30 days, Kennedy is to set nonbinding targets for prescription drug price reductions across all markets of the U.S. He is then to "communicate most-favored-nation price targets to pharmaceutical manufacturers to bring prices for American patients in line with comparably developed nations."

The additional action could include regulatory action to impose most-favored-nation pricing or a ruling that could allow for low-cost drugs to be imported from other countries.

Americans spend $1,126 per capita on drugs, while that number is $240 in Britain.

Kennedy said that if the Europeans raise the price of their drugs by just 20% that is $10 trillion that can be spent on innovation.

Stephen Ubl, president and CEO of the PhRMA trade association, said that importing foreign prices will cut billions of dollars from Medicare.

title: Daniel DePetris: The Trump administration cools off India-Pakistan conflict — for now
content: With last-minute U.S. mediation, cooler heads prevailed between India and Pakistan. But a flare-up is inevitable.
resumen: At a time when the administration of President Donald Trump is trying to cement a short-term ceasefire in Ukraine, end the war in Gaza and strike a comprehensive trade deal with China, the last thing it needed was a conflict between two nuclear-armed rivals. Last week, India and Pakistan, historic adversaries that have fought multiple wars and smaller-scale skirmishes with each other since the 1940s, entered into their most serious armed dispute in years. With last-minute U.S. mediation, cooler heads prevailed. New Delhi and Islamabad found a way to de-escalate, stop the fighting and move toward a future that will hopefully be more benevolent than the past. The core issues dividing these two powers will continue to fester like a wound, which means another flare-up is likely months or years down the line. The latest conflict was sparked on April 22, when terrorists that India claims were based in Pakistan killed 26 tourists in the Indian-controlled part of Kashmir. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi went beyond the actions of previous Indian governments in his response. New Delhi downgraded diplomatic relations with Pakistan, closed the border, reduced the number of Pakistani diplomats on Indian soil and suspended a decadesong water treaty that assured joint access to the Indus Basin. On May 7, the Indian army fired missiles into Pakistan, targeting what it said was terrorist infrastructure. The Pakistanis shot down several Indian combat aircraft, and the Pakistani military launched retaliatory strikes of its own. In addition to the artillery fire in Kashmir, India and Pakistan targeted one another’s air bases. The Trump administration became increasingly nervous at the prospect of a major war erupting in one of the most populous places on the planet. Vice President JD Vance got on the phone with Modi encouraging him to authorize direct communication with Islamabad. Secretary of State Marco Rubio worked the phones as well. Bill Clinton’s administration engaged in mediation efforts in 1999. Despite initial claims of ceasefire violations, the fighting has subsided. Pakistan reopened its airspace, and India reopened the many airports it had shuttered as a precautionary measure. The guns have gone silent along the Line of Control, the de facto border separating Pakistani- and Indian-controlled Kashmir, but not before dozens of people were killed in the bombardment. For India, a war could sour Trump as he tries to finalize a trade deal with New Delhi, and for Pakistan, its already shaky economy couldn’t sustain a resource-intensive conflict. Trump was quick to take credit for the ceasefire. Although India insists it negotiated the truce bilaterally with the Pakistanis, it’s safe to say that any deal would have taken more time if the Americans weren’t poking both sides to get something done, fast. Rubio insisted over the weekend that India and Pakistan will meet at a location to be named later, but there has been no confirmation from New Delhi that these discussions will actually happen. The only talks taking place between the countries are those between military officials to keep the truce intact. Without addressing the systemic issues, no ceasefire between New Delhi and Islamabad is going to last very long. Kashmir, one of the most heavily militarized regions in the world and one that has served as the genesis for bloodshed between the two South Asian powerhouses, will have to be at the top of the list in any peace process. India is governed by an uber-nationalist leader and Pakistan administered by a coalition government in which the military holds most of the sway. Daniel DePetris is a fellow at Defense Priorities and a foreign affairs columnist for the Chicago Tribune.

title: Trump’s tariffs have launched global trade wars. Here’s a timeline of how we got here
content: Long-threatened tariffs from U.S. President Donald Trump have plunged the country into trade wars abroad — all while on-again, off-again new levies continue to escalate uncertainty.
resumen:
**NEW YORK (AP) —**

Long-threatened tariffs from U.S. President Donald Trump have plunged the country into trade wars abroad — all while on-again, off-again new levies continue to escalate uncertainty.

Trump launched a trade war during his first term as well, taking particular aim at China by putting taxes on most of its goods. Beijing responded with its own retaliatory tariffs on a range of U.S. products. Trump used the threat of more tariffs to force Canada and Mexico to renegotiate a North American trade pact, called the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, in 2020.

When President Joe Biden took office, he preserved most of the tariffs Trump had enacted against China, in addition to imposing some new restrictions. But his administration claimed to take a more targeted approach.

Fast-forward to today, and economists stress there could be greater consequences on businesses and economies worldwide under Trump’s more sweeping tariffs this time around — and that higher prices will likely leave consumers footing the bill. There’s also been a sense of whiplash from Trump’s back-and-forth tariff threats and responding retaliation seen over the last few months.

Here’s a timeline of how we got here:

*   **January 20.** Trump is sworn into office. In his inaugural address, he again promises to “tariff and tax foreign countries to enrich our citizens.” And he reiterates plans to create an agency called the External Revenue Service, which has yet to be established. On his first day in office, Trump also says he expects to put 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico starting on Feb. 1, while declining to immediately flesh out plans for taxing Chinese imports.
*   **January 26.** Trump threatens 25% tariffs on all Colombia imports and other retaliatory measures after President Gustavo Petro’s rejects two U.S. military aircraft carrying migrants to the country, accusing Trump of not treating immigrants with dignity during deportation. In response, Petro also announces a retaliatory 25% increase in Colombian tariffs on U.S. goods. But Colombia later reversed its decision and accepted the flights carrying migrants. The two countries soon signaled a halt in the trade dispute.
*   **February 1.** Trump signs an executive order to impose tariffs on imports from Mexico, Canada and China — 10% on all imports from China and 25% on imports from Mexico and Canada starting Feb. 4. Trump invoked this power by declaring a national emergency — ostensibly over undocumented immigration and drug trafficking. The action prompts swift outrage from all three countries, with promises of retaliatory measures.
*   **February 3.** Trump agrees to a 30-day pause on his tariff threats against Mexico and Canada, as both trading partners take steps to appease Trump’s concerns about border security and drug trafficking.
*   **February 4.** Trump’s new 10% tariffs on all Chinese imports to the U.S. still go into effect. China retaliates the same day by announcing a flurry of countermeasures, including new duties on a variety of American goods and an anti-monopoly investigation into Google. China’s 15% tariffs on coal and liquefied natural gas products, and a 10% levy on crude oil, agricultural machinery and large-engine cars imported from the U.S., take effect Feb. 10.
*   **February 10.** Trump announces plans to hike steel and aluminum tariffs starting March 12. He removes the exemptions from his 2018 tariffs on steel, meaning that all steel imports will be taxed at a minimum of 25%, and also raises his 2018 aluminum tariffs from 10% to 25%.
*   **February 13.** Trump announces a plan for “reciprocal” tariffs — promising to increase U.S. tariffs to match the tax rates that countries worldwide charge on imports “for purposes of fairness.” Economists warn that the reciprocal tariffs, set to overturn decades of trade policy, could create chaos for global businesses.
*   **February 25.** Trump signs an executive order instructing the Commerce Department to consider whether a tariff on imported copper is needed to protect national security. He cites the material’s use in U.S. defense, infrastructure and emerging technologies.
*   **March 1.** Trump signs an additional executive order instructing the Commerce Department to consider whether tariffs on lumber and timber are also needed to protect national security, arguing that the construction industry and military depend on a strong supply of wooden products in the U.S.
*   **March 4.** Trump’s 25% tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico go into effect, though he limits the levy to 10% on Canadian energy. He also doubles the tariff on all Chinese imports to 20%. All three countries promise retaliatory measures. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announces tariffs on more than $100 billion of American goods over the course of 21 days. And Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum says her country would respond with its own retaliatory tariffs on U.S. goods without specifying the targeted products immediately, signaling hopes to de-escalate. China, meanwhile, imposes tariffs of up to 15% on a wide array of key U.S. farm exports, set to take effect March 10. It also expands the number of U.S. companies subject to export controls and other restrictions by about two dozen.
*   **March 5.** Trump grants a one-month exemption on his new tariffs impacting goods from Mexico and Canada for U.S. automakers. The pause arrives after the president spoke with leaders of the “Big 3” automakers — Ford, General Motors and Stellantis.
*   **March 6.** In a wider extension, Trump postpones 25% tariffs on many imports from Mexico and some imports from Canada for a month. Trump credited Sheinbaum with making progress on border security and drug smuggling as a reason for again pausing tariffs. His actions also thaw relations with Canada somewhat, although outrage and uncertainty remains. Still, after its initial retaliatory tariffs of $30 billion Canadian (US$21 billion) on U.S. goods, the government says it’s suspended a second wave of retaliatory tariffs worth $125 billion Canadian (US$87 billion).
*   **March 10.** China’s retaliatory 15% tariffs on key American farm products — including chicken, pork, soybeans and beef — take effect. Goods already in transit are set to be exempt through April 12, per China’s Commerce Ministry previous announcement.
*   **March 12.** Trump’s new tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports go into effect. Both metals are now taxed at 25% across the board — with Trump’s order to remove steel exemptions and raise aluminum’s levy from his previously-imposed 2018 import taxes. The European Union takes retaliatory trade action promising new duties on U.S. industrial and farm products. resumen: President Donald Trump’s agreement with China to temporarily slash tariffs for 90 days offered the world a bit of welcome relief. The Trump administration agreed after talks this weekend in Switzerland to pare back its 145% in tariffs charged on imports from China to 30%. The Chinese government chose to reduce its retaliatory import taxes on U.S. goods from 125% to 10% while the sides continue to negotiate. Trump declared the de-escalation of the trade war a victory. The tariffs are now elevated from when Trump took office. The U.S. president and his aides have made it clear that most imports will be taxed at a minimum of roughly 10%. The 10% figure has been Trump’s baseline. Trump’s new 30% tariff on Chinese goods includes 20% tied to China’s role in fentanyl and the 10% baseline applied elsewhere. Trump said on Friday, “We have many deals coming down the line, but we always have a baseline of 10%.” Sectoral tariffs of 25% on autos, steel and aluminum are still in place, with Trump stressing that pharmaceutical drugs will also soon face import taxes. Trump said Monday that he told House Speaker Mike Johnson and Senate Majority Leader John Thune to include tariff revenues when looking at how to pay for their planned income tax cuts. Taisu Zhang, a law professor who studies comparative legal and economic history at Yale University, said the chaos from last month probably was not for nothing. The stock market loved the news. The S&P 500 stock index jumped 3.3% in Monday trading. Michael Starr, vice president of growth at the logistics company Zencargo, said there is “absolutely” going to be a bullwhip effect. University of Michigan economist Justin Wolfers stressed that many people would see the 90-day talks as a short-term positive. Kevin Rinz, a senior fellow at the Washington Center for Equitable Growth, said 30% tariffs are still a cost for businesses and consumers to absorb. Rinz, who worked as an economist in the Obama and Biden administrations, tried to model the impact of the labor market based on Trump’s own premise that any short-term pain from tariffs would eventually result in long-term gains. His analysis found a drop in hiring.

title: MEF: arancel del 10% de Trump no afectó envíos de Perú en abril, pero podría restar 0,5 puntos al PBI en 2025
content: El Gobierno confirmó que EEUU ha iniciado una investigación sobre los envíos de cobre y madera desde Perú. ¿Cuál es la respuesta peruana? Buscar otros compradores, según la ministra de Comercio Exteri ...
resumen: Las exportaciones de Perú crecieron un 17% en abril de 2025, impulsadas por hidrocarburos, metalurgia, agropecuario y textil. Las medidas arancelarias anunciadas por el gobierno de Estados Unidos, encabezado por Donald Trump, han generado incertidumbre en el comercio exterior de Perú, aunque hasta el momento no han afectado significativamente las exportaciones peruanas. El Ministerio de Comercio Exterior y Turismo (Mincetur) informó que las exportaciones peruanas mantuvieron un crecimiento del 17% en abril de 2025 en comparación con el mismo mes del año anterior. Las autoridades peruanas advierten que, de mantenerse estas políticas arancelarias, podrían impactar en más del 0,5% del Producto Bruto Interno (PBI) del país para lo que resta del año. Estados Unidos sigue siendo un mercado relevante para el Perú. La ministra de Comercio Exterior y Turismo, Desilú León Llempén, destacó la importancia de Estados Unidos como socio comercial clave para Perú. Desde la firma del Tratado de Libre Comercio (TLC) entre ambos países en 2009, las exportaciones peruanas hacia Estados Unidos han crecido un 109%, mientras que las importaciones desde ese país han aumentado un 130%. Perú evalúa diversificar mercados y fortalecer relaciones comerciales para mitigar posibles impactos de las políticas arancelarias. El gobierno peruano tomó medidas preventivas para mitigar posibles impactos, incluyendo la conformación de un grupo de trabajo interinstitucional con la participación de Mincetur, Cancillería, el Ministerio de Economía y Finanzas (MEF), el Ministerio de Desarrollo Agrario y Riego (Midagri) y el Ministerio de la Producción (Produce). Este grupo analizó las oportunidades comerciales que podrían surgir en mercados donde los aranceles estadounidenses superaran el 10%, porcentaje que entró en vigor el 5 de abril de 2025. Además, se identificaron aranceles más altos, de hasta el 125%, que se aplicarán a ciertos países a partir del 9 de abril, aunque se anunció una pausa de 90 días para su implementación. Perú mantiene un arancel adicional del 10% ad valorem sobre los productos exportados a Estados Unidos, además de los aranceles preferenciales establecidos en el TLC. Productos como el cobre y la madera están siendo investigados por las autoridades estadounidenses. El gobierno peruano ha diseñado una estrategia basada en tres pilares: apoyar a las pequeñas y medianas empresas, intensificar la diversificación hacia otros mercados alternativos, y continuar brindando asistencia técnica a las empresas peruanas. Se han programado 14 actividades comerciales en 2025, incluyendo 11 ferias y 3 misiones comerciales en sectores como alimentos, manufacturas y vestimenta. Se intensificará la diversificación hacia otros mercados alternativos, especialmente en Europa y Asia. Productos como arándanos, uvas, café, espárragos, paltas, mandarinas y mangos han sido identificados como prioritarios para estos mercados. El puerto de Chancay jugará un papel crucial al facilitar el envío de productos frescos a Asia en menos tiempo. La viceministra de Economía, Denisse Miralles, señaló que las exportaciones no tradicionales de Perú hacia Estados Unidos representan una participación relativamente menor. En 2024, solo el 12,7% de las exportaciones peruanas tuvieron como destino Estados Unidos. Perú tiene ventajas estacionales en productos como arándanos, uvas y espárragos. Se espera la pronta entrada en vigor del protocolo de optimización del TLC con China y el acuerdo comercial con Hong Kong. El intercambio comercial de Perú con países con los que tiene tratados comerciales podría aumentar del 89% al 94% del total comerciado. El gobierno peruano mantiene una comunicación constante con la Oficina del Representante Comercial de los Estados Unidos (USTR).

title: Advertencia de Xi Jinping tras el acuerdo arancelario con EEUU: "Las conductas intimidatorias solo conducen al aislamiento"
content: El presidente chino anima a los países de Latinoamérica y el Caribe a que rechacen las injerencias externas | Cadena SER ...
resumen:
El presidente chino, Xi Jinping, declaró que "las prácticas intimidatorias y prepotentes solo sirven para aislarse" en sus primeras declaraciones tras el acuerdo de rebaja de aranceles alcanzado entre su país y Estados Unidos.

Xi insistió durante su discurso inaugural del IV Foro Ministerial de China y la Comunidad de Estados de Latinoamérica y el Caribe (Celac) que "no hay ganadores en una guerra comercial", un día después de que Washington y Pekín anunciaran una tregua que incluye la rebaja al 30% y 10% de los gravámenes.

El presidente chino ha manifestado su "apoyo" a que los países latinoamericanos y caribeños "rechacen las interferencias externas" y "sigan un camino de desarrollo acorde a sus condiciones nacionales".

China y Estados Unidos cerraron un acuerdo en Suiza para rebajar en un 115% sus aranceles mutuos por 90 días.

Estados Unidos acordó reducir del 145% al 30% sus aranceles para los productos chinos, mientras que China aceptó rebajarlos hasta el 10% con respecto al 125% que estaba vigente.

El volumen comercial entre China y la región superó por primera vez los 500.000 millones de dólares el año pasado.

China proporcionará créditos a la región por valor de 9.000 millones de dólares y fortalecerá la cooperación en materia de seguridad y aplicación de la ley.

En los próximos tres años Pekín invitará anualmente a 300 dirigentes de partidos políticos de los países miembros de la Celac a visitar China para "intercambiar experiencias sobre gobernanza".

A la cita en Pekín asisten cancilleres y representantes de la Comunidad de Estados de Latinoamérica y el Caribe (Celac) y, de forma inédita, los presidentes de Brasil, Chile y Colombia.

title: Investing in the American Dream: Why global millionaires are betting on the US Golden Visa
content: Under the EB-5 programme, individuals can obtain a Green Card by investing a minimum of $800,000 in a US business or project that creates at least 10 full-time jobs for American workers.
resumen: The US EB-5 Immigrant Investor Visa allows individuals to obtain a Green Card by investing a minimum of $800,000 in a US business or project that creates at least 10 full-time jobs for American workers. The EB-5 program offers a direct path to US permanent residency (a Green Card) by investing in projects that create jobs and stimulate the US economy. The US Golden Visa combines the promise of opportunity, education, and security. The EB-5 program is attractive to global citizens. The US EB-5 Immigrant Investor Program offers a path to permanent residency for foreign nationals who invest in the American economy. Investors must contribute $800,000 in a Targeted Employment Area (TEA) or $1.05 million elsewhere into a new business that creates at least 10 full-time US jobs. The program covers the investor, spouse, and unmarried children under 21, with eligibility for US citizenship after five years of residency. Processing times can be lengthy, particularly for applicants from high-demand countries. Investors can choose between direct investments or passive investments through United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) approved Regional Centers. The process involves filing petitions, undergoing USCIS review, obtaining a two-year conditional green card, and later proving job creation to secure permanent residency. After five years, investors may apply for US citizenship if they desire. The US EB-5 Immigrant Investor Visa grants conditional permanent residency, allowing investors to live and work in the US under specific conditions. Initially, investors receive a conditional Green Card valid for two years after approval of the I-526 petition and entry into the US. This conditional status requires investors to prove that their investment has created at least 10 full-time jobs for US workers and that the investment is sustained. After holding a permanent Green Card for five years, an investor may apply for US citizenship if they meet the residency and other eligibility requirements. The principal investor can sponsor only their immediate family as part of the visa application, including the investor’s spouse and unmarried children under the age of 21. While there is potential for a return on investment (ROI), it is typically modest and not guaranteed. The EB-5 Immigrant Investor Program does not have specific educational or professional requirements. Additional expenses like legal fees, regional centre fees, filing costs, and due diligence can bring the total cost to $100,000 to $150,000. To maintain status, you must demonstrate that the US is your primary residence. The EB-5 Immigrant Investor Program provides a pathway to US citizenship. As a US Green Card holder, you are considered a tax resident and must report and pay taxes on worldwide income. The US Gold Card Visa, is a proposed immigration initiative designed to provide affluent foreign nationals with a fast-tracked route to US permanent residency and eventual citizenship in return for a $5 million investment. The EB-5 is based on economic contribution and job creation, whereas the Gold Card—if it ever becomes law—would be based purely on financial payment.

title: China's Xi slams 'bullying' as Beijing hosts LatAm leaders
content: Chinese President Xi Jinping vowed Tuesday to deepen ties with Latin America and condemned "bullying" in a thinly veiled swipe at the United States, as he addressed regional leaders in ...
resumen:
China criticó a Estados Unidos y se presentó como defensora del orden multilateral el martes, buscando profundizar lazos con líderes latinoamericanos y caribeños en una cumbre en Beijing.

El presidente Xi Jinping prometió miles de millones en créditos de desarrollo y una mayor cooperación en el China-CELAC Forum, sin nombrar a Estados Unidos, diciendo que "el acoso y la hegemonía solo conducirán al autoaislamiento".

Dos tercios de los países de América Latina se han adherido a la iniciativa de infraestructura de la Franja y la Ruta (BRI) de Beijing, y China ha superado a Estados Unidos como el mayor socio comercial de Brasil, Perú, Chile y otros.

Xi dijo que "no hay ganadores en las guerras arancelarias o comerciales" y que "solo a través de la unidad y la cooperación los países pueden salvaguardar la paz y la estabilidad globales y promover el desarrollo y la prosperidad en todo el mundo".

El líder chino prometió $9.2 mil millones en préstamos para el "desarrollo", como parte de un amplio conjunto de iniciativas destinadas a profundizar la cooperación, incluso en infraestructura y energía limpia.

Beijing también cooperará en la lucha contra el terrorismo y la delincuencia transnacional organizada, así como en la mejora de intercambios como becas y programas de capacitación.

El acuerdo del lunes anunciado en Ginebra, Estados Unidos acordó reducir sus aranceles sobre los productos chinos al 30 por ciento, mientras que China reducirá los suyos al 10 por ciento.

El acuerdo marcó una importante desescalada entre las dos economías más grandes del mundo.

Una tasa del 20 por ciento sobre las quejas de Trump sobre las exportaciones chinas de productos químicos utilizados para fabricar fentanilo, una droga opioide que ha matado a miles de estadounidenses, sigue vigente.

El Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores de Beijing exigió el martes que Estados Unidos "deje de difamar y culpar" por la crisis de los opioides.

Wang Yi, sin nombrar a Estados Unidos, condenó a una "gran potencia" que está "obsesionada con la idea de que la fuerza es el derecho".

Instó a las naciones latinoamericanas a "unir sus manos" con China para defender sus derechos contra un país que "utiliza los aranceles como arma para intimidar a otros países".

Wang calificó la reunión como un "gran éxito" y agregó que el "mercado supergrande combinado de dos mil millones de personas" entre China y América Latina proporcionaría nuevos motores de crecimiento para ambas partes.

Entre los asistentes notables al foro se encontraba el presidente brasileño Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, quien llegó a Beijing el sábado para una visita de estado de cinco días.

Lula dijo que su región no "quiere repetir la historia y comenzar una nueva Guerra Fría".

En conversaciones con su homólogo brasileño el martes, Xi dijo que los dos países deberían "fortalecer la cooperación" y juntos "oponerse al unilateralismo".

Los dos países emitieron una declaración conjunta diciendo que "acogen con satisfacción la propuesta del presidente ruso Vladimir Putin de iniciar conversaciones de paz" con Ucrania, calificando el diálogo directo como "la única forma de poner fin al conflicto".

También estuvo presente en el foro el presidente colombiano Gustavo Petro, quien pidió un "diálogo entre civilizaciones" que tuviera en cuenta los intereses de la región.

Petro tiene la intención de firmar un acuerdo para unirse a la BRI de un billón de dólares de Beijing durante su visita.

El presidente chileno Gabriel Boric también dijo al foro que su país daría un "salto adelante en las relaciones económicas con China".

title: Esperando a que se abra la puerta blanca
content: Siguen sumándose a diario los costos adicionales a las exportaciones de Guatemala, debido a la política indiscriminada de aranceles impuesta por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump.
resumen:
Siguen sumándose a diario los costos adicionales a las exportaciones de Guatemala, debido a la política indiscriminada de aranceles impuesta por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump.
Dicha nación le vende a Guatemala más del doble de lo que nuestro país exporta a ese mercado.
El 10% de aranceles a los productos guatemaltecos es necesario agilizar la negociación para regresarlos a cero, en virtud del tratado DR-Cafta.
El reclamo estadounidense sobre barreras comerciales abarca áreas más bien procesos y requisitos burocráticos que impiden un mejor, más eficiente y competitivo ingreso de productos y servicios estadounidenses en el mercado guatemalteco.
La delegación económica guatemalteca tiene pendiente recibir cita para reunirse con la Oficina del Representante de Comercio de Estados Unidos (USTR, en inglés), para exponer los avances y calendarizar la solución de pendientes.
La delegación estaría integrada por personal del Ministerio y delegados empresariales.
Una de las barreras es la demora portuaria y aduanera para el ingreso de mercancías.
Otro valladar citado por Estados Unidos es la gran cantidad de trámites necesarios para el comercio, algunos de los cuales todavía se efectúan en papel.
Ello abarca a ministerios como el de Salud y Agricultura, principalmente.
El Mineco ya lleva a cabo una nueva criba para poder mostrar avances en el esperado diálogo.
La certeza jurídica, tanto por los vacíos legales remanentes como por la tardanza de procesos judiciales y la notoria discrecionalidad con la cual se manejan ciertas judicaturas; todo el aparato de justicia debería estar implicado en solventar este lastre, que incluye la propiedad intelectual y la seguridad para las inversiones.
Los servicios del Estado a la inversión, el respeto a los derechos laborales y la lucha contra la corrupción son mencionados en el pliego de barreras que Estados Unidos demanda resolver para considerar el levantamiento de los aranceles.
Cada semana transcurrida bajo esta penalización implica costos adicionales para la productividad nacional.

title: Xi Jinping corteja a América Latina y presenta a China como el antídoto ante la "intimidación" de Trump
content: En la semana en la que China presume de haber logrado que Donald Trump cediera en su guerra comercial tras llegar a un acuerdo de suspensión de la mayoría de aranceles, ...
resumen:
El presidente chino, Xi Jinping, recibió en Pekín a líderes latinoamericanos y altos funcionarios de la región.

Los líderes de las tres mayores economías de América Latina viajaron a Pekín para participar en una cumbre con el gigante asiático.

En el evento estuvieron el brasileño Lula da Silva, acompañado por 11 ministros y 150 empresarios, el chileno Gabriel Boric y el colombiano Gustavo Petro.

Xi Jinping abrió el foro China-CELAC con declaraciones sobre la "intimidación" y el "aislacionismo", dirigidas a la administración Trump.

Xi anunció el compromiso de proporcionar 66.000 millones de yuanes (alrededor de 8.000 millones de euros) en fondos de crédito a la región.

China es el principal socio comercial de Sudamérica y el segundo más importante de América Latina en su conjunto, después de Estados Unidos.

El comercio bilateral entre China y América Latina pasó de 18.000 millones de dólares a 450.000 millones en 20 años.

China tiene acuerdos de libre comercio con cinco naciones y más de una veintena de proyectos en marcha bajo el plan de infraestructuras de Pekín, la nueva Ruta de la Seda.

Xi apadrinó un mega puerto en Chancay, Perú, y se planea unir por ferrocarril el puerto peruano con la costa atlántica de Brasil.

Xi discutió acuerdos con Lula da Silva, incluyendo cooperación en inteligencia artificial y exploración espacial.

Lula defendió la unión contra el unilateralismo y el proteccionismo.

Empresas chinas han invertido en Argentina, Venezuela, Brasil y Chile.

Dos entidades financieras chinas han prestado más de 120.000 millones de dólares a gobiernos latinoamericanos desde 2005.

title: Trump da un paso atrás para contener efectos nocivos de su guerra comercial, señala Maduro
content: Caracas, 12 may (Sputnik).- El acuerdo alcanzado entre China y EEUU sobre reducir aranceles recíprocos por un lapso de 90 días demuestra que el presidente Donald Trump dio un paso atrás para "contener ...
resumen:
El acuerdo alcanzado entre China y EEUU sobre reducir aranceles recíprocos por un lapso de 90 días demuestra que el presidente Donald Trump dio un paso atrás para «contener los efectos nocivos» de su «guerra comercial» contra la nación asiática, dijo el presidente de Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro, el lunes durante la transmisión de su programa televisivo.

Maduro dijo que Trump reconoció en Ginebra el poder económico de China y que la única forma que su economía no se destrozara, se desabasteciera y los precios crecieran enloquecidamente en Estados Unidos era llegar a un acuerdo rápido y urgente con China.

Según una declaración conjunta publicada en la web de la Casa Blanca, el acuerdo entre las partes se produce después de que mantuvieran del 10 al 11 de mayo conversaciones de alto nivel en Suiza, en medio de una escalada de la guerra comercial entre ambos países.

Maduro acusó a EEUU de «agredir» al mundo al propiciar una «guerra arancelaria» contra China.

Maduro dijo que Trump dio marcha atrás a su política contra Pekín debido al poder económico mundial que representa la nación asiática.

Se señala que EEUU suspenderá unos 24 puntos porcentuales del arancel adicional, impuesto mediante la Orden Ejecutiva 14257 a las mercancías procedentes de China «durante un período inicial de 90 días», y que eliminará otros adicionales, impuestos por la Orden Ejecutiva 14259 la Orden Ejecutiva 14266.

China procederá a una suspensión y un recorte simétricos, y eliminará los aranceles adicionales anunciados en las semanas recientes y adoptará las medidas administrativas necesarias para suspender o eliminar las contramedidas no arancelarias impuestas contra Estados Unidos desde el 2 de abril de 2025.

Washington recorta los aranceles generales sobre los productos chinos del 145 por ciento al 30 por ciento y Pekín rebaja los derechos de aduana sobre las importaciones estadounidenses del 125 por ciento al 10 por ciento.

title: Tariff pause to provide breather
content: Despite the de-escalation of the tariff war between the United States and China, uncertainties still linger in the economy as negotiations continue to take place during the 90-day pause.
resumen: The United States and China agreed to suspend most tariffs on each other’s goods for 90 days, reducing reciprocal tariffs between both nations to 10% from 125%. The United States will maintain its 20% duties on Chinese imports relating to fentanyl, keeping total tariffs on China at 30%. Universiti Tunku Abdul Rahman economics professor Wong Chin Yoong said there is a high likelihood that the 10% baseline levy will remain in place after the 90-day period. Sunway University economics professor Yeah Kim Leng said the thaw has reduced substantially a major headwind to global growth outlook, portending a partial reversal of the projected decline of global trade and investment flows in the second half of 2025 (2H25). The full-year gross domestic product (GDP) growth forecast for Malaysia is expected to nudge up to the upper end of the forecast range. The International Monetary Fund’s (IMF) forecast for Malaysia is 4.1%. Yeah added the good news from the US-China breakthrough is that it will ease the negotiation path for the other countries, with the 10% baseline tariff remaining as the minimum threshold. Yeah is of the view that the bulk of GDP increase in 1Q25 will be contributed by domestic demand. Malaysia’s growth prospects in 2025 remain well supported by resilient domestic demand, strong pipeline of domestic and foreign direct investment projects, a well-capitalised and liquid banking and financial system and ongoing structural reforms. Acceleration in exports from front-loading activities was largely expected to boost 1Q’s GDP growth. Economist Geoffrey Williams said 1Q25 GDP is likely to register a good performance due to the ramp-up in trade ahead of the US tariff announcement. The earlier downgrades in economic forecasts by international agencies and various research houses will have to be revised upwards. Last month, the IMF downgraded its real GDP growth forecast for Malaysia to 4.1% this year, from its January estimate of 4.7%. Moody’s Analytics also lowered its forecast for domestic 2025 GDP growth to 4.4% from 5%. OCBC senior Asean economist Lavanya Venkateswaran said the house view on Malaysia’s economic growth forecasts remains unchanged amidst the new tariff outcomes. The final estimate of 1Q25 GDP is expected to be the same as the Statistics Department’s advance estimate of 4.4% year-on-year (y-o-y). In 1Q25, exports grew 4.4% y-o-y to RM378.36bil, down from a 7.3% y-o-y increase in 4Q24 to RM392.97bil. The statistics department’s advance 1Q25 GDP estimate of 4.4% may be revised up slightly to 4.5%. Centre for Market Education (CME) chief executive officer Dr Carmelo Ferlito pointed out that growth in GDP per se is not necessarily a positive thing and is dependent on the underlying components and how that growth is achieved. Bank Negara held the overnight policy rate (OPR) steady at 3%, unchanged since May 2023. The central bank also cut the statutory reserve requirement (SRR) by 100 basis points to 1%, a move that is expected to inject RM19bil in liquidity into the banking system. Universiti Tunku Abdul Rahman’s Wong said the latest easing of US-China tensions would mean it is more likely that OPR will be maintained in July, with a potential rate cut likely to take place in September. He now anticipates a smaller downward revision in GDP growth, trimming earlier estimates from 1 to 1.5 percentage points (ppt) to a more moderate range of 0.5 to 1 ppt at most. Williams does not see the need for interest rate cuts. Bank Negara’s mandate is to support stable prices, sustainable growth and a strong financial system.

title: La gran lección que nos deja la tormenta arancelaria de abril
content: Los aranceles aprobados el pasado mes resultaron ser mayores, más variados y, sobre todo, más disparatados de lo que nadie había previsto, ni siquiera Milei. Las tasas universales del 10% y los ...
resumen:
La guerra arancelaria de Donald Trump ha sacudido las bolsas y solo se vislumbra incertidumbre.

Tras un mes de abril surrealista, intentar prever los movimientos de los mercados con información ampliamente comentada o vender en momentos de pánico carece de sentido.

Los mercados descuentan con rapidez las noticias y opiniones más comentadas.

Las decisiones anunciadas el 2 de abril fueron de tal dimensión que nadie las esperaba, dando paso a una sorpresa negativa.

Los aranceles aprobados y previstos eran de poca importancia.

El presidente Javier Milei elogió los planes de Trump mientras pensaba en lograr un acuerdo comercial con Estados Unidos.

Los aranceles aprobados resultaron ser mayores, más variados y, sobre todo, más disparatados de lo que nadie había previsto, ni siquiera Milei.

Las tasas universales del 10% y los impuestos “recíprocos”, mucho más elevados, agudizaron la incertidumbre.

La renta variable mundial se desplomó y se agravaron las pérdidas del Merval.

Los mercados no pueden anticipar una sorpresa tan absurda y de tal magnitud.

Los supuestos aranceles recíprocos no son recíprocos en absoluto, no tienen nada que ver con los que otros países aplican a Estados Unidos.

El arancel medio de la UE es del 2,7%, y se le ha impuesto un 20%.

El gravamen medio de Vietnam es del 5,1%, y Trump se lo ha subido al 46%.

Los aranceles se calcularon en función del déficit comercial de Estados Unidos con cada país, alegando que los estaban “engañando”.

El tipo universal del 10% también afecta a países con los que EEUU mantiene un superávit comercial, como Argentina.

Las balanzas comerciales nunca predicen, por sí solas, los buenos resultados económicos.

Francia ha registrado déficits comerciales anuales desde 2008, mientras que Alemania, superávits, pero el desempeño económico de Francia fue ligeramente mejor.

Los superávits comerciales no son negativos, ya que las balanzas comerciales no significan ni predicen nada.

Milei está eliminando las barreras al libre comercio.

El 9 de abril Trump suspendió los aranceles “recíprocos” durante 90 días a todos los países menos a China, a la que impuso un castigo adicional.

Las acciones estadounidenses y argentinas subieron más del 9,5% ese día (en USD).

La mayoría de las sesiones a la baja se agrupan alrededor de los días de volatilidad al alza, de modo que es imposible anticiparse a los movimientos del mercado.

Incluso si volvieran a entrar en vigor los aranceles, el efecto sería menor de lo que se teme.

No hay sistemas ni personal suficientes para gestionar su recaudación.

El Departamento de Recaudación del Servicio de Aduanas y Protección de Fronteras de Estados Unidos solo dispone de 2.500 empleados y su tecnología está obsoleta.

Desde el 5 de abril hasta mediados de mes apenas recaudó 500 millones de dólares de los 2000 millones diarios previstos por Trump.

Esta tendencia continuará mientras las empresas puedan eludir una parte de los pagos.

Los aranceles universales exceden el ámbito de la Ley de Emergencia Nacional, invocada por Trump, y ya hay demandas en curso.

Es posible que veamos acuerdos para reducir las barreras comerciales, con el potencial alcista que eso supondría.

Otros países, al margen de China, podrían adoptar represalias, pero no parece probable.

Pregúntese si sabe algo sobre los aranceles de Trump que los demás ignoran.

Salvo que disponga de información desconocida y no haya sido descontada en las cotizaciones, realizar cambios en la cartera en pleno episodio de volatilidad es cuestión de suerte.

En caso de que necesite una rentabilidad a largo plazo similar a la de la renta variable para financiar sus objetivos, salir del mercado es muy arriesgado.

title: Si Colombia se adhiere a la Franja y la Ruta de China, ¿qué sigue? Esto firmaron otros países de América Latina
content: Los escenarios y efectos de lo que el presidente Gustavo Petro pactaría en Pekín. ¿Acuerdo deberá ser revisado?
resumen:
El presidente Gustavo Petro mencionó la posibilidad de firmar la "ruta de la seda" con China, refiriéndose a la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta (BRI).

La BRI, creada en 2013 por el presidente Xi Jinping, es una plataforma de cooperación entre países, con énfasis en el sur global.

América Latina comenzó a vincularse en 2018, con 22 países miembros actualmente, aunque Panamá anunció su retiro. Brasil, México y Paraguay no se han adherido.

La adhesión a la BRI se realiza a través de un memorando de entendimiento.

Los memorandos de entendimiento son figuras no vinculantes del derecho internacional.

El Gobierno Nacional aún no ha revelado el memorando de entendimiento entre Colombia y China.

Los analistas coinciden en que el memorando no tendría que pasar por el Congreso ni la Corte Constitucional.

Después de la firma, la acción bajaría al nivel ministerial para coordinar diálogos con China.

Después de la firma, dependerá de la iniciativa de China y Colombia por generar acercamientos comerciales.

Los memorandos de entendimiento de Argentina, Panamá y Ecuador con China tienen una estructura similar.

Los memorandos enfatizan en la cooperación, el desarrollo económico mutuo, el comercio bilateral, las inversiones y la cooperación tecnológica.

Las tres áreas prioritarias de cooperación son: coordinación de políticas, conectividad de infraestructura, facilitación del comercio e inversiones, integración financiera y el vínculo entre los pueblos.

Los documentos enfatizan en los "principios de mercado" y la participación conjunta de capital público y privado.

La vigencia inicial en los tres documentos es de tres años, renovable automáticamente.

La eventual firma del memorando de entendimiento tendría efectos políticos y económicos.

La adhesión podría ser vista como un gesto geopolítico sensible y una señal de posible realineamiento estratégico.

Una adhesión formal podría afectar la confianza política, la cooperación en seguridad y la percepción de Colombia como socio prioritario de Estados Unidos.

title: América latina teme la caída de las remesas
content: Más allá de la geopolítica que pretende redibujar fronteras, o cambiar de pronto tratados internacionales como el del Canal de Panamá, o subvertir alianzas tradicionales como la de Estados Unidos con ...
resumen:
Las clases populares de América Latina temen la drástica caída de las remesas de los emigrantes.
Una parte importante de la población de América Latina sobrevive gracias al envío de remesas de dinero de sus familiares en el exterior.
La inflación por los cambios económicos por aplicación de nuevos aranceles, retracción económica, o cualquier otra causa, va a limitar la capacidad de ahorro de esos inmigrantes, preferentemente los hispanos en Estados Unidos.
En sus últimas previsiones, el Fondo Monetario Internacional advertía de un posible retroceso del crecimiento de la economía mundial en medio punto, que llegaba hasta un punto de caída en Estados Unidos por el impacto de las decisiones económicas de Donald Trump.
El entonces gerente del Fondo Monetario Internacional, Rodrigo Rato, mostró con detalle en sus estudios el impacto de las remesas en una parte importante de los países del mundo.
Se sabe de la existencia de remesas y de una potente estructura comercial de casas de envíos de dinero; pero no se conoce cuán vital es esa aportación para la vida y la estabilidad de tantos países.
Hay noticia de la suspensión o aplazamiento de viajes turísticos a Estados Unidos -primer destino mundial, al que siguen España y Francia- hasta que lleguen tiempos más seguros.
Las agencias turísticas españolas estiman en unos doce mil los viajeros que han desistido por el momento de esas vacaciones, en los últimos tres meses, optando por destinos menos arriesgados.

title: Magín Díaz: Aranceles de Trump son “irracionales” y amenaza estabilidad económica
content: Durante una entrevista en el programa El Sol de la Tarde, Díaz expresó: “La política de Donald Trump, de arancel, es tan irracional que él no la va a poder aplicar completamente. Al final, es posible ...
resumen:
Magín Díaz, economista y exdirector de la Dirección General de Impuestos Internos (DGII), advirtió que la política arancelaria propuesta por el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump es «irracional» y difícilmente aplicable en su totalidad.

Consideró que un eventual arancel del 10 % no desencadenaría una catástrofe mundial, aunque sí podría generar distorsiones comerciales significativas para países como la República Dominicana.

Díaz expresó: “La política de Donald Trump, de arancel, es tan irracional que él no la va a poder aplicar completamente. Al final, es posible que se queden esos aranceles de 10 %, tal vez hasta más bajos. Si es 10 %, bueno, eso es lo que hay. Eso no va a crear una catástrofe mundial”.

El principal problema no es tanto el nivel del arancel, sino la aleatoriedad y la imprevisibilidad que caracterizan las decisiones del mandatario.

Esa incertidumbre afecta negativamente a los exportadores dominicanos, quienes ya sienten el impacto del aumento de costos por estos aranceles, aunque en algunos casos la tasa efectiva podría ser menor si hay insumos importados desde Estados Unidos involucrados en el proceso de producción.

“Tal vez ese 10 % se convierte en 7 % u 8 % con los descuentos, pero el verdadero peligro es que Estados Unidos entre en una recesión. Eso sí nos arrastra a nosotros directamente, porque somos muy dependientes de esa economía”, advirtió.

Díaz también alertó sobre los intentos de Trump por intervenir en la política monetaria y presionar a la Reserva Federal, una acción que considera gravemente perjudicial.

Recordó el precedente histórico del presidente Richard Nixon, quien en los años 70 presionó al presidente de la Reserva Federal para reducir las tasas de interés prematuramente, lo que resultó en una década de alta inflación en Estados Unidos.

“Una de las peores cosas que puede hacer un presidente es interferir con la independencia del Banco Central. Un Banco Central no está para ganar concursos de popularidad, está para tomar decisiones que, aunque impopulares, estabilizan la economía a largo plazo”, sentenció.

Afirmó que, aunque mantener tasas de interés altas puede desacelerar la economía, es una medida preferible a permitir un nuevo brote inflacionario.

Valoró como acertadas las decisiones actuales de la Reserva Federal de mantener el control inflacionario, aunque estas medidas sean impopulares entre los políticos.

En relación con la situación económica local, Díaz abordó el impacto de la inflación en el sector construcción.

Explicó que, aunque la inflación ha bajado, los precios no han retornado a niveles anteriores, acumulando aumentos de entre 40 % y 60 % en algunos insumos en los últimos cuatro años.

“Cuando se controla un choque inflacionario, la inflación baja, pero eso no significa que los precios retrocedan. El costo acumulado sigue ahí. La economía tiene que adaptarse a esa nueva realidad, y eso puede tardar años”, señaló.

Sugirió que el Gobierno puede aplicar políticas anticíclicas, como la expansión del gasto público y el endeudamiento, para impulsar el crecimiento económico, especialmente ante una posible desaceleración.

Subrayó que esas decisiones implican dilemas fiscales importantes.

“No se puede criticar al Gobierno simplemente por endeudarse. Lo importante es que esa deuda sirva para acelerar la economía y contrarrestar los efectos de una desaceleración. Son decisiones difíciles, pero necesarias en algunos momentos”, concluyó.

title: What’s next with Trump’s trade war truce with China
content: The Trump administration agreed after talks this weekend in Switzerland to pare back its 145% in tariffs charged on imports from China to 30%. The Chinese government chose to reduce its retaliatory ...
resumen: President Donald Trump’s agreement with China to temporarily slash tariffs for 90 days offered the world a bit of welcome relief. The Trump administration agreed after talks this weekend in Switzerland to pare back its 145% in tariffs charged on imports from China to 30%. The Chinese government chose to reduce its retaliatory import taxes on U.S. goods from 125% to 10% while the sides continue to negotiate. Trump declared the de-escalation of the trade war a victory, saying he would soon chat with Chinese President Xi Jinping about how to preserve the financial relationship between the world’s two largest economies. The tariffs are now elevated from when Trump took office and the scramble to respond to the White House’s mix of threats and olive branches might leave CEOs, investors and consumers uneasy and unwilling to take risks. Trump is going to keep tariffing. The global economy is not going to back to January 19, 2025, the day before Trump became president. Even if he routinely changes the tariff rates, the U.S. president and his aides have made it clear that most imports will be taxed at a minimum of roughly 10%. The 10% figure has been Trump’s baseline. He gave it to most countries for a 90-day negotiating period after his April 2 “Liberation Day” tariff rollout caused a panic in the financial markets. He kept the 10% rate as part of the framework with the United Kingdom announced last week. Trump’s new 30% tariff on Chinese goods includes 20% tied to China’s role in fentanyl and the 10% baseline applied elsewhere. Trump said on Friday, “We have many deals coming down the line, but we always have a baseline of 10%.” Sectoral tariffs of 25% on autos, steel and aluminum are still in place, with Trump stressing that pharmaceutical drugs will also soon face import taxes. Trump said Monday that he told House Speaker Mike Johnson and Senate Majority Leader John Thune to include tariff revenues when looking at how to pay for their planned income tax cuts. Taisu Zhang, a law professor who studies comparative legal and economic history at Yale University, said the chaos from last month probably was not for nothing. Both countries were testing their strengths, with Trump stressing the importance that foreign companies placed on accessing U.S. consumers and China emphasizing its resilience to an external shock. Chinese President Xi Jinpin attends a signing ceremony with Russian President Vladimir Putin. The stock market loved the news and could shape what happens next. The world has seen that Trump remains wary of getting on the wrong side of the financial markets. When his initial April 2 announcement of higher tariff rates fueled a selloff in stocks and rising interest rates on U.S. debt, he retreated by announcing his 90-day suspension of tariffs so that talks could proceed with nations other than China. The S&P 500 stock index jumped 3.3% in Monday trading, helping validate the Trump administration’s decision to lower tariff rates so that talks could proceed. Michael Starr, vice president of growth at the logistics company Zencargo, said there is “absolutely” going to be a bullwhip effect in which the shortages now turn into a rush of new supply as companies try to beat the prospect of higher tariffs returning. University of Michigan economist Justin Wolfers stressed that many people would see the 90-day talks as a short-term positive because “moving tariffs from prohibitive and insane to merely very high is good news.” A problem for Trump is that businesses have already made plans for the 145% tariffs he announced earlier and might be hesitant to revise them until any permanent policies are set. Kevin Rinz, a senior fellow at the Washington Center for Equitable Growth, said, “Maybe some of those could live with 30%, at least for a while, but in 90 days, what are tariffs with China going to be? Will they go up or down from 30%? If up, how far? I have no idea, and if I were a firm that relies on imports from China, that would cause paralysis.” Rinz, who worked as an economist in the Obama and Biden administrations, tried to model the impact of the labor market based on Trump’s own premise that any short-term pain from tariffs would eventually result in long-term gains. His analysis found a drop in hiring.

title: It’s Not Just Trump’s Tariff War Hurting BC’s Forest Sector
content: Every Canadian lumber producer that invests south of the border or is considering doing so is also “tariff jumping,” Antweiler said, which means increased profit margins potentially at the expense of ...
resumen:
In August 2022, Canfor Corp. announced plans to spend more than US$200 million to build a new high-tech sawmill in southern Alabama. The Mobile County Industrial Development Authority offered Canfor $14.2 million in combined property and sales tax incentives.

An investigation by The Tyee shows that Canfor, Interfor, and West Fraser have invested nearly US$8.4 billion to buy, expand, or build 59 mills in about a dozen U.S. states over the past 20 years, making the bulk of those investments in Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North and South Carolina and Texas.

The U.S. lumber producers accuse Canadian provinces of subsidizing logging companies through low stumpage fees, which they say resulted in Canada “dumping” softwood lumber into the United States.

Events in B.C., where the bulk of Canada’s lumber exports originate, are equally important. Thanks to decades of logging at rates that the companies and provincial government alike knew could not be sustained, one B.C. mill after another has closed while forestry giants turn their attention to the U.S. South, where the trees grow far faster.

In 1987 and 1988, both were record-setting for the number of trees logged. Those years also marked another first as B.C. adjusted to a new 15 per cent export charge imposed by the U.S. Department of Commerce on imported Canadian lumber.

The favourable difference in the currencies was pivotal in keeping B.C. lumber makers in the game in the lucrative U.S. market. To improve profit margins, they built new supersized mills that upped the amount of lumber produced while lowering the number of workers needed to do the job.

The new threatened doubling of the duties Canadian lumber producers would pay on U.S.-bound lumber shipments — to 34.45 per cent from 14.4 per cent — will likely mean more B.C. mill closures and corresponding increases in Canadian forest company investments south of the border.

The Tyee’s review shows that between them the three companies have, since 2004, spent more than US$8.4 billion in today’s dollars to buy, upgrade and build a combined 59 mills in 13 U.S. states.

From 1988 through the end of 2024, B.C. lumber producers shipped a combined 923 million cubic metres of lumber to buyers outside Canada, including the United States, China and Japan, with the value of those shipments worth a combined $327 billion in today’s dollars. The United States’ share of those exports was 667 million cubic metres of lumber at a combined sales value of $211.6 billion, or $5.71 billion on average per year.

In 2024, B.C.’s lumber shipments to the United States were just shy of 11.3 million cubic metres. In 2005, U.S. buyers bought more than 28.6 million cubic metres of lumber from B.C. lumber makers. In 2021, the total volume of lumber exported from B.C. to the United States stood at 14.3 million cubic metres, half of what it was in 2005.

In each decade from the 1980s on, at the provincial government’s urging, logging companies in B.C. dramatically increased the number of trees they cut down in response to significant insect infestations.

For seven years beginning in 2001, lumber exports to the United States were at their highest and most sustained levels in history. In all, more than 174 million cubic metres of lumber were shipped south in those years.

B.C. frequently set its stumpage rates charged on the trees logged in designated beetle salvage-logging zones at 25 cents per cubic metre.

Canadian lumber producers have paid billions of dollars in duties on their U.S.-bound lumber, duties held by the U.S. Department of Commerce. With the interest accrued on those payments since 2017, the total amount paid approaches US$9 billion.
