title: China Courts Lula and Latin America After Trump’s Tariff Shock
content: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil is visiting Beijing this week, and China’s Xi Jinping will also meet top officials from other Latin American and Caribbean nations to emphasize their ties ...
resumen:
President Trump wants Latin American countries to shift closer into Washington’s orbit, raising echoes of the Monroe Doctrine.

This week, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, is hosting President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil and other leading officials from Latin America and the Caribbean in Beijing.

Many Latin American governments also want to keep Beijing onside — chiefly as an economic partner, but for some also as a counterweight to U.S. power, experts said.

China’s assistant foreign minister, Miao Deyu, told reporters in Beijing on Sunday, according to the People’s Daily, “What the people of Latin America and the Caribbean seek are independence and self-determination, not the so-called ‘new Monroe Doctrine.’”

The U.S. secretary of state, Marco Rubio, has said that the Trump administration will be “putting our region, the Americas, first,” and Mr. Rubio’s first overseas trip as secretary was to Panama, Guatemala and other countries in the region.

Mr. Trump’s sweeping tariffs and threats to take over the Panama Canal have unsettled leaders in Latin America.

Matias Spektor, a professor of politics and international relations at Fundação Getulio Vargas, a Brazilian university, said, “Lula sees China as a partner in rebalancing global power, not just a trade partner but a geopolitical counterweight to U.S. hegemony.”

“Lula’s strategy is clear: diversify Brazil’s alliances, reduce dependency on Washington, and assert Brazil as a mover and shaker in an increasingly multipolar world.”

Mr. Lula is the most prominent of the leaders assembling in Beijing for a meeting on Tuesday between Chinese officials and ministers from the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States, or CELAC, a group that does not include the United States or Canada.

Colombia’s president, Gustavo Petro, will also attend, Chinese media reported.

Over the past two decades, China became a prodigious purchaser of minerals and other resources from Brazil, Peru, Chile and other Latin American customers.

Last year, trade in goods between China and Latin America reached nearly $519 billion.

Mr. Lula has, for all his friendliness to Beijing, increased tariffs on iron, steel and fiber optic cable, products that mostly come from China.

Ryan Berg, the director of the Americas Program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, said countries across Latin America are “hugely concerned” that Chinese exporters shut out of the U.S. market will divert cheap goods there, swamping local manufacturers.

Mexico, the second-biggest Latin American economy after Brazil, has so far taken a more cautious approach to courting China.

Mexico now accounts for about 2.4 percent of China’s total exports.

Enrique Dussel Peters, a professor of economics at the National Autonomous University of Mexico, said, “Mexican elites and the government are torn in this new triangular relationship” with the United States and China.

Mr. Xi has sounded optimistic that he can keep Mr. Lula and many other major Latin American leaders onside, partly through plain persistence, and partly through continued orders of iron ore, soybeans and other commodities.

Mr. Lula has also voiced hopes that China can help Brazil make gains in new technologies, including space and green energy.

When Mr. Xi traveled to Brazil for a G20 leaders’ summit in November, he added on a state visit there.

He is expected to visit Rio de Janeiro for a summit in July of the BRICS group of developing countries that was founded by Brazil, Russia, India and China.

Joseph R. Biden’s only visit to Brazil as president — for the G20 summit — came only after he had lost the presidential election.

Mr. Berg said, “The fact that we are much closer, but we have had high-level visits with less frequency than Xi is a barrier to regional prioritization and a bad sign from a strategic perspective.”

Professor Spektor said, “China’s demand underpins Brazil’s economic stability.”

title: These locals want Trump to win the battle for the Panama Canal
content: Huddled together on a dirt bank outside a building site on the edge of the Panama Canal, the men shout fervidly about Donald Trump.
resumen:
The Panama Canal has become a political issue.

Some construction workers are cheering for Donald Trump, who pledged to "take back" the waterway. They believe the canal benefits only a few "elites" and want Trump's intervention.

Trump has claimed the canal is under Chinese control.

A Hong Kong-based firm, CK Hutchison Holdings, manages two ports adjacent to the canal. The Trump administration has pressured the firm to sell those interests to a US consortium that includes BlackRock Inc.

A Chinese spokesman insisted the country "will as always respect Panama’s sovereignty".

The Panama Canal is run by the Panama Canal Authority, and only Panamanians are entitled to work on it.

A Chinese consortium won a $1.4 billion contract to build the canal’s fourth bridge. Local workmen claim they have been disregarded in favor of foreigners.

Marvin Moreno, a welder, supports Trump.

Trump has criticized former president Jimmy Carter for returning the canal to Panama.

The US is the canal’s biggest user, with some 40 per cent of all US container traffic crossing it each year.

Trump dispatched Marco Rubio and Pete Hegseth to Panama. Hegseth delivered a press conference stating: “We will take back the Panama Canal from China’s influence.”

Following Rubio’s visit, José Raúl Mulino said he had made an “important” decision to pull out of China’s Belt and Road Initiative.

A Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) was signed, giving US military vessels free passage of the canal and allowing US troops to return to three areas on Panamanian soil for joint military training.

Ricardo Lombana, the leader of Panama’s opposition, called it an "invasion".

Javier Martínez-Acha, Panama’s foreign affairs minister, insisted the deal “does not imply a surrender of sovereignty, nor does it violate the national constitution, nor the neutrality treaty”.

Trump demanded both US military and commercial ships be given free passage through the Panama and Suez canals.

Jorge Quijano, the former administrator of the Panama Canal Authority, was surprised by Trump’s allegations.

Sebastian King, special adviser for the union of marine engineers, believes the US allowed China to win infrastructure projects.

title: Banano y otros rubros ticos afectados por aranceles estadounidenses
content: San José, 12 may (Prensa Latina) Los exportadores costarricenses de piña, banano, café y dispositivos médicos encabezan la lista de los que sufrirían el mayor impacto ante los aranceles del 10 por cie ...
resumen:
Los exportadores costarricenses de piña, banano, café y dispositivos médicos encabezan la lista de los que sufrirían el mayor impacto ante los aranceles del 10 por ciento anunciados por Estados Unidos, según una experta local.

El impacto preciso dependerá de la elasticidad de la demanda de estos productos y de quién finalmente asumirá el costo adicional.

Es de esperarse que las exportaciones disminuyan de forma marcada en rubros como el café, explicó la economista y profesora en gestión de riesgos Anelena Sabater.

Casi la mitad de los bienes vendidos en 2024 en el extranjero fueron a Estados Unidos; la fuerte vinculación con aquel país hace que Costa Rica sea susceptible de sufrir un fuerte golpe por los referidos aranceles impuestos por el presidente Donald Trump.

Un análisis del Centro Internacional de Política Económica para el Desarrollo Sostenible estimó caídas significativas respecto a 2024 en colocaciones hacia Estados Unidos: bajas de un 8 por ciento en piña, 18 por ciento en banano y 19 por ciento en café sin tostar.

El sector industrial de dispositivos médicos se vería golpeado con una reducción estimada del 10 por ciento de las ventas hacia un socio principal con el que la dependencia comercial costarricense es profunda.

La nación centroamericana exportó a Estados Unidos en 2024 bienes por nueve mil millones de dólares, lo cual representó un 47 por ciento del total de 19 mil millones de dólares enviados en total hacia el exterior, de acuerdo con datos de la Promotora de Comercio Exterior.

La imposición de aranceles amenaza con golpear no solo a exportadores, sino a toda la economía nacional, y sus efectos serían múltiples: menos empleo, reducción de la inversión extranjera, un tipo de cambio más alto y un freno al crecimiento económico.

title: Piña, banano, café y dispositivos médicos tendrán una reducción de exportaciones entre 8% y 19% por aranceles de EE.UU.
content: Crecimiento económico Como principal socio comercial, un golpe a la economía estadounidense se traduciría en un menor crecimiento para Costa Rica. Ya se está estimando un crecimiento país que ...
resumen:
Piña, banano, café y dispositivos médicos tendrán una reducción de exportaciones entre 8% y 19% por aranceles de EE.UU.

En 2024, el país exportó bienes a Estados Unidos por un total de $9 mil millones, lo que representó un 47% del total de los $19 mil millones enviados al exterior, según datos de la Promotora de Comercio Exterior (Procomer).

Los exportadores costarricenses de dispositivos médicos, piña, banano y café encabezan la lista de sectores que sufrirían el mayor impacto ante los aranceles del 10% anunciados por Donald Trump, presidente de Estados Unidos.

Anelena Sabater, economista y profesora en gestión de riesgos, señala que estos productos serían los más expuestos a la nueva política comercial estadounidense.

El Centro Internacional de Política Económica para el Desarrollo Sostenible (Cinpe) de la Universidad Nacional (UNA), estima caídas significativas en las colocaciones hacia Estados Unidos: un 8% menos en piña, un 18% menos en banano y un 19% menos en café sin tostar respecto a 2024.

En el caso del sector industrial de dispositivos médicos, se vería golpeado con una reducción estimada del 10%.

Según Cinpe, sin aranceles, la producción costarricense crecería un 3,6% en 2025, pero con la carga arancelaria, esa cifra caería a un 3%.

Dónald Miranda, investigador de la UNA, indica que las proyecciones de crecimiento económico de Costa Rica se enmarcan en dos posibles escenarios, los cuales dependen principalmente del comportamiento del comercio internacional, la evolución de la economía de Estados Unidos y las condiciones de política monetaria interna.

La caída en exportaciones, turismo e inversión extranjera reduciría la oferta de dólares, presionando al alza el tipo de cambio.

El Banco Central ya mantiene su política monetaria firme ante la coyuntura con una tasa de política monetaria de 4%.

resumen: The United States and China have reached an agreement to help resolve the trade war between the world's two largest economies, senior Trump administration officials announced Sunday, The Post reported. The details of the deal, reached during negotiations in Switzerland over the weekend, were not disclosed, but officials said more information will be shared on Monday. US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer said, "The United States has an enormous trade deficit of $1.2 trillion, so the president declared a national emergency." President Trump imposed tariffs of up to 145% on products from China, while the Asian country applied retaliatory tariffs on US exports. The meeting between the United States and China was held in Geneva. Greer joined Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng in talks in Geneva over the weekend to address the three-digit tariff. China is the third most important trading partner of the United States and has long angered Trump for its practices, which include the export of lethal fentanyl, currency manipulation, intellectual property theft, forced technology transfers and more. According to some estimates, China's annual theft of intellectual property from the United States ranges from $225 billion to $600 billion. Last year, the United States had a trade deficit of $295.4 billion with China. During his second term, Trump imposed a 20% tariff on China, seeking concessions in the fentanyl crisis. Trump administration officials claim to have made notable progress with China in just two days. On Saturday, Trump boasted of the "great progress made" in deliberations with China. content: Para el diplomático y académico chileno Fernando Reyes Matta, director del Centro de Estudios Latinoamericanos sobre China, la región debe abordar esta relación con una mirada estratégica y autónoma, ...
resumen:
Latinoamérica evalúa su autonomía geopolítica frente a China y EEUU.

El IV Foro Ministerial China-Celac se celebrará el 13 de mayo en Pekín.

China, como mayor socio comercial de muchos países de la región, pretende ampliar su influencia política y multilateral.

América Latina redefine su lugar en el tablero geopolítico, con la guerra comercial y tecnológica entre China y EEUU como telón de fondo.

Fernando Reyes Matta, director del Centro de Estudios Latinoamericanos sobre China, afirma que la región debe abordar esta relación con una mirada estratégica y autónoma.

El foro se realiza en paralelo al primer diálogo formal entre China y EEUU en Ginebra.

Colombia, que ostenta la presidencia pro tempore de la Celac, ha señalado que este foro representa una oportunidad clave para definir el rumbo político de la región.

El presidente Gustavo Petro busca consolidar una plataforma de cooperación multilateral que no esté subordinada a las potencias tradicionales.

El viceministro Mauricio Jaramillo indica que la Celac se proyecta en dos niveles: el intra Celac y la proyección extrarregional, donde China se convierte en un interlocutor estratégico.

El presidente Petro estará en Pekín junto a sus homólogos de Brasil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, y Chile, Gabriel Boric.

China llega a esta cumbre como el mayor socio comercial de muchos países de la región y busca ampliar su influencia política y multilateral.

La región no acude al foro con una voz unificada.

Brasil, Chile y Bolivia buscan una relación estratégica con China sin romper puentes con Occidente.

Argentina, bajo el mandato de Javier Milei, ha dado un giro drástico en favor de Washington.

El Brasil de Lula mantiene su interés en una reforma del sistema multilateral.

Claudia Sheinbaum, presidenta de México, ha adoptado una postura pragmática, priorizando el Tratado de Libre Comercio con Estados Unidos y Canadá (T-MEC).

Sheinbaum impulsa el “Plan México” para reducir la dependencia de productos importados de Asia.

El foro China-Celac se ha convertido en una plataforma para discutir proyectos regionales en infraestructura, tecnología, energía limpia y conectividad.

En países como Nicaragua, Honduras y El Salvador, el discurso de Pekín encuentra eco.

Uruguay busca acuerdos comerciales bilaterales con China más allá del consenso del Mercosur.

El IV Foro Ministerial China-Celac servirá para hacer balance del Plan de Cooperación Conjunta 2022-2024 y sentar las bases de una nueva hoja de ruta que guíe las relaciones hasta 2027.

Temas como el cambio climático, la salud pública, la educación y la digitalización estarán en el centro del debate.

El desafío para Latinoamérica es construir una relación con China que aproveche las oportunidades sin caer en una nueva dependencia.

title: Asia Stocks Rise on Hope for Lower Tariffs After U.S.-China Talks
content: Investors were optimistic after American officials touted progress in trade negotiations over the weekend, though details had yet to be released.
resumen:
Stocks surged around the world after U.S. and Chinese officials said they agreed to temporarily suspend most of the tariffs they have imposed on each other.

Futures for the S&P 500 suggested that U.S. stocks would open nearly 3 percent higher when trading begins in New York on Monday morning. Futures for the tech-heavy Nasdaq climbed nearly 4 percent.

The S&P 500 dropped almost 20 percent below its peak in February, but it has since rebounded, recovering roughly two-thirds of its losses as various exemptions and pauses to U.S. tariffs have been announced.

In a joint statement, released on Monday after weekend talks in Geneva, the United States and China said they had reached an agreement to reduce their respective tariffs for 90 days while trade negotiations continue.

The United States would reduce the tariff on Chinese imports to 30 percent from its current 145 percent, while China would lower its import duty on American goods to 10 percent from 125 percent.

After the statement’s release, the U.S. dollar strengthened against a wide range of currencies. U.S. Treasury yields also rose.

Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index jumped about 3 percent, while the Stoxx Europe 600 index rose about 1 percent. Oil prices, which are sensitive to expectations of global economic growth, also rose, gaining more than 3 percent.

Over the weekend, Washington and Beijing held their first meetings since ratcheting up tit-for-tat trade barriers on each other, effectively blocking much of the trade between the countries.

After the trade conversations concluded, however, officials from both sides touted significant progress.

That was enough to edge stocks higher in Japan, South Korea and mainland China during the Asia trading day.

“The conflict between the United States and China over tariffs has passed a major hurdle,” said Takahide Kiuchi, executive economist at the Nomura Research Institute in Tokyo. The Trump administration is wary of tariffs dealing a major blow to the U.S. economy and therefore it is unlikely that levies will be raised higher than 100 percent again, he said.

The stocks most exposed to global trade flows surged on the news. For example, A.P. Moeller-Maersk and Hapag-Lloyd, two of the world’s largest shipping companies, jumped more than 10 percent.

Economists have warned that U.S.-China trade tensions significantly increased the possibility of an economic downturn.

The World Trade Organization has forecast that the continuing division of the global economy into “rival blocs” could cut global gross domestic product by nearly 7 percent over the long run.

In April, the International Monetary Fund lowered its 2025 outlook for all Group of 7 nations, including Germany and Japan, the world’s third- and fourth-largest economies, due largely to U.S. tariffs.

Last week, China reported that its exports to the United States in April dropped 21 percent from a year earlier.

title: PLD ve grandes desafíos para la RD debido a guerra arancelaria
content: Santo Domingo, 10 may (EFE).- El exministro de Economía Temístocles Montás advirtió que gestionar las amenazas y riesgos que plantea la guerra arancelaria y reducir los impactos sobre el crecimiento e ...
resumen:
El exministro de Economía Temístocles Montás advirtió que gestionar las amenazas y riesgos que plantea la guerra arancelaria y reducir los impactos sobre el crecimiento en el largo plazo, representan «grandes desafíos» para el país.

El vicepresidente del Partido de la Liberación Dominicana (PLD) afirmó que la política arancelaria del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, no sólo ha alterado las relaciones económicas entre grandes potencias, sino que ha generado ondas expansivas que amenazan la estabilidad y el crecimiento de las economías en desarrollo.

Para la República Dominicana, con una economía abierta, pequeña y fuertemente dependiente del comercio internacional, la inversión extranjera y la estabilidad del entorno global, el clima de incertidumbre generado por la política de Trump es especialmente perjudicial.

Montás apuntó que la guerra arancelaria ha marcado un cambio profundo en el comercio internacional, ha erosionado el multilateralismo y el libre comercio, base del orden económico global establecido tras el fin de la Segunda Guerra Mundial.

Al imponer aranceles unilaterales a casi todos los países, incluidos China, México, Canadá y a la Unión Europea, el presidente Trump ha despertado una ola de proteccionismo que ha contribuido a un clima de creciente incertidumbre económica internacional.

República Dominicana tiene que plantearse «seriamente» un rediseño de su modelo económico hacia una mayor diversificación de los destinos de las exportaciones y de la canasta exportadora, reducir la dependencia de un solo mercado y fortalecer el mercado interno.

title: Aceite, electrónica, relojes, arte o tabaco de 'shisha': las exportaciones de Málaga a EE UU bajo amenaza por los aranceles de Trump
content: Entre las importaciones destacan los medicamentos, las turbinas y turbogeneradores, los carritos de golf o las cortadoras de césped ...
resumen:
Las exportaciones de Málaga a EE UU, incluyendo aceite de oliva, electrónica, relojes, arte y tabaco de 'shisha', están bajo amenaza por los aranceles de Trump.
En 2024, las exportaciones de Málaga a EE UU sumaron 308 millones de euros.
El aceite de oliva es el principal producto de exportación, representando el 72% del total (casi 222 millones de euros).
En 2024, la provincia alcanzó un récord histórico de ventas al mercado americano y un superávit comercial de más de 213 millones con EE UU.
Otros productos agroalimentarios exportados incluyen vino (más de 3 millones de euros en vino blanco en 2024, y 1,3 millones en otras variedades), aceitunas (más de 2 millones de euros), vinagre, pescado en salazón y azafrán.
También se exportan dispositivos de control domótico, paneles solares (casi 5,7 millones de euros facturados el año pasado), condensadores eléctricos, componentes electrónicos, relojes de alta gama (4 millones de euros) y obras de arte (casi 916.000 euros).
Las importaciones desde EE UU incluyen maquinaria, drones, barcos, medicamentos, carritos de golf, cortadoras de césped y pinzas de batería.
Hay 738 empresas malagueñas que exportaron a EE UU el año pasado, de las cuales 124 han mantenido relación comercial durante los últimos cuatro años.
Estados Unidos es el cuarto cliente más importante para los exportadores malagueños después de Francia, Italia y Portugal.
La Cámara de Comercio de Málaga reconoce que la situación es "complicada" para las empresas malagueñas.
Se aconseja a las empresas "intentar seguir trabajando en el mercado americano, mientras sea rentable" y "trabajar para diversificar las exportaciones en otros mercados".
Latinoamérica y Mercosur ganan atractivo como mercados alternativos.
Otros mercados interesantes son Colombia, México, Arabia Saudí, la India y Canadá, así como África subsahariana.
Reino Unido, Marruecos y China también son destinos de exportación importantes.
Las exportaciones de servicios, como las de empresas tecnológicas (Babel, Hispasec), estudios de arquitectura e ingeniería, compañías de formación (Vértice) y bufetes de abogados, no se ven afectadas por los aranceles.

title: How much inventory did companies actually build ahead of tariffs?
content: To what degree does today’s economic activity reflect a pull forward of purchases that would’ve occurred further down the road?
resumen:
**Main Content:**

*   A significant economic question is the degree to which current economic activity reflects a pull-forward of purchases due to anticipated tariffs.
*   Companies have been pulling forward purchases and stockpiling goods to mitigate the impact of future tariffs.
*   Quotes from Citigroup, UPS, Apple, Amazon, Kraft Heinz, and WD-40 indicate companies are accelerating imports and building inventory.
*   Deutsche Bank's Binky Chadha estimates excess imports over the last 3 months were about $190 billion, or around 3 weeks extra.
*   Companies typically maintain about 3 months of inventory, but have been raising that buffer, especially since the COVID pandemic.
*   Chadha estimates companies have about 1 to 2 months of buffer before tariff impacts start to bite.
*   BofA analysts express skepticism toward the idea that warehouses are well stocked, citing a surge in consumer goods imports in March, but also consumers buying ahead.
*   Goldman Sachs' David Kostin concludes that 1Q data do not show a buildup of inventories, with the S&P 500 inventory-to-sales ratio declining.
*   The March retail sales report showed an unusual spike in auto sales, supporting the idea of consumers pulling forward purchases.
*   The uncertainty around tariffs remains a significant issue.
*   The Federal Reserve left its target for the federal funds rate unchanged at a range of 4.25% to 4.5%.
*   Fed Chair Powell stated that sustained large increases in tariffs are likely to generate a rise in inflation, a slowdown in economic growth, and an increase in unemployment.
*   Chase Consumer Card spending data was 2.2% above the same day last year as of April 29, 2025.
*   BofA reports credit and debit card spending per household increased 1% year-over-year in April, with a seasonally adjusted annualized growth rate of 1.6%.
*   Initial claims for unemployment benefits fell to 228,000 during the week ending May 3, down from 241,000 the week prior.
*   Median inflation expectations were unchanged at the one-year-ahead horizon at 3.6% and increased by 0.2 percentage point at the three-year-ahead horizon to 3.2%.
*   Gas prices are ticking lower, with the national average at $3.15.
*   The Manheim Used Vehicle Value Index increased to 208.2, an increase of 4.9% from a year ago.
*   The Atlanta Fed’s wage growth tracker shows the median hourly pay in April was up 4.3% from the prior year.
*   Nonfarm business sector labor productivity decreased 0.8% in the first quarter of 2025.
*   The average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was unchanged at 6.76%.
*   S&P Global’s May U.S. Services PMI indicates business activity and hiring have come closer to stalling in April.
*   The U.S. trade deficit widened to a record in March to $140.5 billion.
*   The New York Fed’s Global Supply Chain Pressure Index remains near historically normal levels.
*   Peak day office occupancy was 63.3% on Tuesday last week.
*   The Atlanta Fed’s GDPNow model sees real GDP growth rising at a 2.3% rate in Q2.

title: Trump’s trade deals may support the S&P 500, offering nervous investors an opportunity to sell
content: SINGAPORE] More than a month after US President Donald Trump’s “Liberation Day”, he is giving the world a glimpse at what it will take to get him to relent on the hefty tariffs he has slapped on most ...
resumen:
A string of unfinished trade deals could give Trump a pretext to roll back tariffs if the economic pain becomes too much to bear.

The US and UK announced an “economic prosperity deal”, which will see tariff-free beef exports between the US and UK, and the UK reduce its tariff on US ethanol to zero. The US will reduce its industry-specific tariffs on UK cars, steel and aluminium. The US will maintain its baseline reciprocal tariff of 10 per cent on most imports from the UK.

The US and China also began trade discussions over the weekend in Switzerland, with Trump floating the possibility of cutting US tariffs on Chinese goods if the talks are substantive.

US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said last week that the US-China talks will initially focus on de-escalating the tensions between the two nations.

The US-UK Economic Prosperity Deal is still a work-in-progress that could take months or even years to complete.

If the US maintains its baseline reciprocal tariff of 10 per cent on its trading partners, it would represent long-term headwinds for global trade.

After tumbling more than 12 per cent over just four trading sessions following Liberation Day, the S&P 500 has regained almost all the ground it lost. The benchmark US stock index ended last week at 5,659.91 – just 0.2 per cent below where it closed before the Liberation Day tariffs were announced.

The US dollar index (DXY) ended last week at 100.42 – down about 3.3 per cent since Apr 2, and down 7.4 per cent since the beginning of this year.

For most trade-oriented economies in Asia, the tariffs would essentially amount to a major demand shock. For the US, the impact is likely to be a significant supply shock as well as a demand shock.

On Apr 30, the US Bureau of Economic Analysis said US gross domestic product in Q1 2025 shrank 0.3 per cent.

US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell said last week that the import surge was likely to have been driven by businesses bringing in goods early to avoid the increased tariffs. Private domestic final purchases grew a solid 3 per cent in Q1 2025, the same as last year’s pace.

Powell also warned that Trump’s tariffs could put the Fed’s dual-mandate goals of maximum employment and stable prices in conflict. “If the large increases in tariffs that have been announced are sustained, they are likely to generate a rise in inflation, a slowdown in economic growth and an increase in unemployment,” he noted.

The US central bank said last week that it would maintain the target range for the federal funds rate at between 4.25 and 4.5 per cent. Powell said this policy rate is “in a good place” as the Fed awaits further clarity on the tariffs and their impact on the US economy. The median projection of participants at the March meeting was that there would be two 25-basis-point rate cuts in 2025.

Some companies – including Ford, Mattel and UPS – declined to provide any updated guidance in light of all the uncertainty.

With the S&P 500 now back at its pre-Liberation Day levels, I’m inclined to use the opportunity to lighten my exposure to the US market.

Asian investors have been pulling out of the US market in favour of Europe and China – or simply cash and gold.

The S&P 500 is still trading at higher earnings multiples than the Stoxx Europe 600, the Nikkei 225 and the Hang Seng Index.

title: Nevada truckers who backed Trump now grapple with trade war fallout
content: The dramatic escalation of Trump’s tariffs on Chinese imports — with rates soaring to 145% on select goods — creates significant hardship for Nevada’s trucking sector.
resumen: Steve Finn, owner of Premium Trucking in Las Vegas, voted for President Donald Trump in November. Finn supports Trump’s vision to revitalize domestic production through tariff-centered strategy, but he is critical of how these trade policies have been executed. The dramatic escalation of Trump’s tariffs on Chinese imports — with rates soaring to 145% on select goods — creates significant hardship for Nevada’s trucking sector. Many local operators depend on consistent freight contracts from the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach, which serve as the principal entry points for Chinese merchandise into American markets. The critical West Coast hubs experienced a striking 44% reduction in shipping traffic compared with the previous year’s figures. Finn says about one-third of his company’s business comes from the port of Los Angeles. He’s already seen a 20% drop in trucks transloaded from the port. Truline Corp. President Paul Truman operates a trucking company out of Las Vegas with a fleet of more than 300 trucks. The lag time between products arriving at the port docks and making their way to Las Vegas stores could “be as short as two weeks.” Shashi Nambisan, director of UNLV’s Transportation Research Center, said it takes three to four weeks for a Chinese product to get to a California port, and a few days to get it offloaded and on its way to Las Vegas. Gene Seroka, executive director of the Port of Los Angeles, said retailers have around three to five weeks of full inventory in the tank. Trump said in an interview with ABC News late last month, “at 145 (percent), they basically can’t do much business with the United States.” His treasury secretary, Scott Bessent, has said the same, calling the tariffs a de facto embargo. Nambisan believes the Trump administration has moved far too quickly. It could take companies anywhere from a couple of months to a year to move their production out of China to a less-tariffed country. Moving production to the U.S.? That’s at least a year, if not a few, to get production running with a workforce that can operate it, Nambisan said. Paul Enos, CEO of the Nevada Trucking Association, is still hopeful. A CNBC poll of CEOs found a third expected to make job cuts this year due to tariffs. In another April poll, nearly two-thirds of CEOs said they expected a recession within the next six months. Finn said it was impossible to prepare for the slowdowns at the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach. Much of Finn’s business relies on conventions. The CES tech extravaganza each January sets the tone at the start of the year. Truman says he feels like he’s in a good position with growth last year and some new accounts to start 2025, but if the economy sours — like multiple institutions in Nevada believe will happen — “it’s going to affect everybody.” Enos said he wasn’t worried about the trade war being prolonged. Data analysis firm CarrierOK reported that 88,000 trucking companies closed in 2023. Nambisan said a drop in shipping to Southern California’s ports would be proportional to its impact on Las Vegas’ trucking companies; a 25% drop in inflows would mean a 25% drop in transport along Interstate 15 between the two metro areas. Finn said he wouldn’t pull the lever for Trump again if given the opportunity today. Enos, who also voted for Trump, hasn’t wavered in his support.

title: 4 Reasons You Should Stand Pat on Walmart Stock Amid Tariffs and Inflation, According to Experts
content: Walmart's CEO told Trump his tariffs could affect global supply chains and "lead to empty shelves." Does that spell bad news for its business and stock?
resumen: CEO Doug McMillon of Walmart, along with the CEOs of Target and Home Depot, met with President Donald Trump to warn him about how sweeping tariffs could slam the retail sector and economy at large. They told Trump his tariffs could affect global supply chains and “lead to empty shelves.” The closed-door meeting, held on Monday, April 21, had an immediate impact. Scott Bessent, the Treasury secretary, said the administration would try to de-escalate the tariff situation with China, CNN reported. Trump also backed off earlier threats to remove Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell. About two weeks after Trump won a second term in November, Walmart’s chief financial officer, John David Rainey, said the retailer might have to raise prices on certain items if Trump made good on his tariff threats, CNBC reported. Walmart’s stock has performed pretty well in 2025, rising over 8% year to date while the broader markets have slumped. Edward Corona, a Florida-based trader and publisher of The Options Oracle Newsletter, said, “When the CEOs of Walmart, Target and Home Depot show up together, it’s not a social call. It’s a collective, ‘Hey, these tariffs are going to hurt everyone, especially our customers.’” Anthony Grosso, a New York-based financial strategist and mortgage loan originator, said, “Walmart’s whole business is built on having the lowest prices around — cheaper than pretty much anyone else. That’s always done well for them. With all the talk lately about tariffs, especially with China, any new ones are going to hit their bottom line.”

title: U.S. Farm economy is starting to see first hits from Trump tariffs
content: Donald Trump’s tariffs are upending crop trading, delaying tractor purchases and constraining imports of chemical supplies into the U.S.
resumen:
Donald Trump’s tariffs are upending crop trading, delaying tractor purchases and constraining imports of chemical supplies into the U.S.

The disruptions in global trade threaten to extend a years-long slump in the U.S. farm industry, which had already been struggling with ample supplies, depressed crop prices and rising competition from Brazil.

Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. and Bunge Global SA saw their combined operating profits slump by about $750 million in the first quarter.

Importers put off purchases of U.S. grain and oilseeds as Trump threatened tariffs as well as levies on any Chinese vessels docking at American ports.

Tractor makers CNH Industrial NV and AGCO Corp. also reported lower first-quarter sales.

Shipments of phosphate into the U.S. have trailed last year’s levels because vessels have been diverted to other countries to avoid the nation’s 10 per cent tariff, Mosaic Co. said in its earnings statement.

Nutrien Ltd. said its branded products could potentially cost as much as 7.5 per cent more, with even higher adjustments expected for generic ingredients.

Minerva SA said tariff turmoil drove increased Chinese demand and higher export prices for South American beef in the first quarter, helping lift profits for the Brazilian supplier.

China has effectively shut its market for U.S. meat exporters including Smithfield Foods Inc.

China has already shifted to Brazil for a meaningful part of its soybean needs since Trump first raised tariffs on goods from the Asian nation in 2018.

title: Three good reasons why the US dollar has further to fall
content: The movement in the US dollar against the major currencies has gone into something of a holding pattern over recent weeks as the currency markets await fresh developments on the US’s trade war with ...
resumen:
Roger J Kerr outlines why the US dollar is still at risk to a further leg downwards from current levels.

Summary of key points:
- Currency markets pause USD selling – however there is more to come!
- On the verge of a new US dollar cycle.
- NZ employment data defies the negative forecasts.

The movement in the US dollar against the major currencies has gone into something of a holding pattern over recent weeks as the currency markets await fresh developments on the US’s trade war with the rest of the world and also a clearer direction and messaging from the Federal Reserve as to when their next change will be with interest rates.

The US dollar will have a period of consolidation following the rapid collapse from 110.00 on the Dixy Index in January to lows of 98.00 last month. The USD Index has returned to 100.00 as the EUR/USD rate has corrected back from highs of $1.1550 to the $1.1200/$1.1300 area.

The pause in US dollar selling is also related to a view that perhaps the worst is behind us in terms of the impact of Trump’s tariff attack on the US and global economy. If progress is made by de-escalating the negative impact of tariffs on the US economy by negotiated trade deals and lower tariff levels finally agreed, the reasons for selling the US dollar over the last three months would be reduced.

As a consequence of the USD recovery and stabilisation, the NZD/USD exchange rate has not been able to push through higher above the 0.6000 barrier and has remained in its tight trading range between 0.5900 and 0.6000.

The Americans and Chinese have agreed to meet in Geneva this weekend to discuss tariffs and trade. The financial markets would be expecting far too much if they think that a deal to reduce tariffs to workable levels on both sides would be a result of this first meeting. These trade discussions are likely to go on for months.

Against the backdrop of more settled FX markets over recent weeks, there are still three good reasons why the US dollar is still at risk to a further leg downwards from current levels:

- Asian exporters selling out of USD cash surpluses: Asian exporting companies have hoarded massive US dollar cash reserves over the last decade. It has been reported that up to USD2.5 trillion is currently held in USD’s by Asian exporters and institutional investors. China, Taiwan, Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam all run trade surpluses with the US and to date those surpluses have been held in USD. The Asian holders of USD cash reserves have a big incentive to sell before the USD depreciates any further.
- Global fund manager’s reducing USD portfolio weights: Fund managers have been over-weight USD asset classes over the last five years. Australia’s Future Fund Chief Executive, Raphael Arndt has warned that “the Trump administration’s protectionist policies threaten the US dollar’s status as the dominant global currency and could force investors to reduce their holdings”. The Future Fund at USD240 billion in assets is ranked 17th largest in the world.
- The Federal Reserve’s next big decision: Chair Powell at the Fed meeting last week was adamant that he has the luxury of time to wait and see how the economic data emerges over coming months before making a decision to adjust interest rates downwards again. The uncertainty and risk around rising inflation and softening employment had escalated in the Fed’s view. The Fed also seem reluctant to recognise the forward-looking “soft” economic data such as deteriorating consumer and business confidence surveys. The Fed need to trust the soft forward-looking data and act sooner rather than later with interest rate cuts. When they realise the risk is greater with rising unemployment than permanent inflation, they should have sufficient evidence to cut interest rates at their 18th June meeting. Such a shift in the Fed’s stance would be negative for the US dollar.

All three of the above-described forces on the US dollar working in tandem at the same point in time, certainly increases the probability of another leg lower in the USD Dixy Index to 95.00 over coming weeks/months.

Over the last 55 years since 1970, the US dollar has posted three major up-cycles (1980-85, 1992-2000 and 2010-2024) and three major down-cycles (1970-1980, 1985-1992 and 2000-2010). Previous cyclical lows for USD in the 80.0 to 90.0 region were in 1978-1980, 1991-1995 and 2009-2012.

The stronger USD cycle from 2010 to 2025 has been much longer in duration than the other cycles because of US economic exceptionalism due to superior productivity gains from technological innovation. The new Trump regime’s policies to put up a protective wall around the US economy and to stop being a policeman to global conflicts, suggests that the period of US exceptionalism is coming to an end, and therefore the USD cyclical gains are also coming to an end.

To make US manufacturing competitive again (as Trump pines for), it is clear that simple product costing and pricing requires a lower US dollar value. Given the massive capital exodus from the US over recent months, the next cyclical downturn in USD may transform into a more structural weakening.

Consensus forecasts beforehand were for the New Zealand unemployment rate to increase from 5.10% in the December 2024 quarter to 5.30% in the March 2025 quarter. The result was an unchanged unemployment rate at 5.10%.

The growing evidence from the export boom taking place in regional New Zealand would point to an entirely different GDP growth trajectory for the NZ economy this year. The public sector right-sizing in Wellington and Auckland construction firms reducing worker’s hours is certainly negatively impacting the retail and residential property sectors in our two big cities. However, economic conditions in the provinces have certainly turned up sharply. Record high dairy, beef and lamb prices (despite tariff uncertainties) are driving increased spending and investment. Any nationwide business in New Zealand today will tell you that sales in Auckland and Wellington are down on budget, but the rest of the country is well ahead of budget. Higher export prices stimulate increased investment and production, which in turn require more labour. Outside of Auckland and Wellington, employment is growing, and it is only a matter of time before in transfers through into the property-dominated Auckland economy.

title: U.S. and China Meet for Second Day of Trade Talks
content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Jamieson Greer, the United States Trade Representative, are leading the talks for Washington. For Beijing, the negotiations are being led by He Lifeng, China’s ...
resumen: Top economic officials from the United States and China met on Sunday in Geneva for their second day of high-stakes negotiations. The talks are aimed at easing tensions stemming from President Trump’s trade war. Mr. Trump has imposed a minimum tariff of 145 percent on all Chinese imports, while China has hit American products with a 125 percent import tax. American companies at risk of bankruptcy are scrambling to source products from countries other than China. Chinese factories are shuttering their doors, or looking for ways around the U.S. tariffs and exporting more to Southeast Asia. Many U.S. businesses are weighing how much they can increase prices to help offset the tariff costs. The two sides met to negotiate in Geneva. Dozens of officials from the countries were camped out on Saturday and Sunday at the residence of the Swiss ambassador to the United Nations. After roughly seven hours of talks on Saturday, the United States said it would not release any formal statement about the proceedings. Mr. Trump wrote on Truth Social on Saturday night: “A very good meeting today with China, in Switzerland. Many things discussed, much agreed to. A total reset negotiated in a friendly, but constructive, manner.” Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative, are leading the talks for Washington. For Beijing, the negotiations are being led by He Lifeng, China’s vice premier for economic policy. Mr. Trump quickly ratcheted up his tariffs on China in recent months. The Trump administration has also accused China of unfairly subsidizing key sectors of its economy and flooding the world with cheap goods. The United States has been pressuring China to take more aggressive steps to curb exports of precursors for fentanyl. Mr. Trump initially added a 20 percent tariff to Chinese exports. When the president announced global tariffs at the beginning of April, he added an additional 34 percent tariff on China. Mr. Trump quickly raised tariffs on Chinese products to a minimum of 145 percent. Ahead of the meetings in Geneva, Mr. Trump suggested that he would be open to lowering those tariffs to 80 percent. The White House spokeswoman, Karoline Leavitt, said that China would have to make concessions for the tariffs to be reduced. The United States is expected to press China not just on the issue of tariffs and fentanyl shipments, but also on its other export bans that threaten U.S. companies. Beijing placed export restrictions on key minerals and magnets. China has been steadfast in saying it does not intend to make trade concessions in response to Mr. Trump’s tariffs. Nancy Vanden Houten, U.S. economist at Oxford Economics, wrote in a research note on Saturday. Ms. Vanden Houten explained that even if the United States reduced the tariff rate on Chinese imports to 80 percent, the overall effective tariff rate for imports would be three times higher than projections from when Mr. Trump was elected. Some analysts and executives have said that tariffs above 50 percent are generally high enough to prohibit trade. Mr. Trump appears poised to declare that any concessions made by China are a win for the United States. Mr. Trump declared: “GREAT PROGRESS MADE!!!”

title: EEUU busca un “reinicio total” en su relación comercial con China, afirma Trump
content: El mandatario estadounidense destacó los “grandes avances” logrados en el primer día de conversaciones en Suiza sobre la guerra arancelaria.
resumen: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, expresó ayer sábado su expectativa de lograr un “reinicio total” de las relaciones comerciales entre Estados Unidos y China, tras el primer día de conversaciones entre delegaciones de alto nivel de ambos países en Suiza. Trump elogió el “muy buen” diálogo en la ciudad suiza de Ginebra, destinado a rebajar las tensiones comerciales después de que Estados Unidos impusiera fuertes aranceles a productos procedentes de China, lo que provocó duras medidas de represalia por parte de Beijing. “Una reunión muy buena hoy con China en Suiza. Se discutieron muchos temas y se llegó a muchos acuerdos. Se negoció un reinicio total de forma amistosa pero constructiva. Por el bien tanto de China como de EEUU queremos ver una apertura de China a las empresas estadounidenses. ¡¡¡GRANDES AVANCES!!!”, escribió Trump. Las delegaciones de Estados Unidos y China concluyeron el primero de dos días de negociaciones directas sobre la guerra arancelaria. Los equipos negociadores están encabezados del lado estadounidense por el secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent, y el representante de Comercio, Jamieson Greer, y por el viceprimer ministro He Linfeng del lado chino. Scott Bessent, secretario del Tesoro de EEUU, encabeza la delegación de conversaciones con China en Ginebra. El Gobierno chino señaló a través de sus medios oficiales que al aceptar entrar en estas negociaciones demuestra su sentido de responsabilidad. También reconoció que reforzar la comunicación bilateral será mutuamente beneficioso para entender las respectivas preocupaciones y “evitar malas interpretaciones”. Por su parte, la base del diálogo para la parte americana la dictó en la víspera el propio Trump al afirmar que bajar del actual 145% al 80% los aranceles a China le parece “apropiado”. El país asiático está aplicando a su vez a Estados Unidos unos gravámenes del 125%. La cumbre de este fin de semana en Ginebra es el primer encuentro de alto nivel desde el inicio de la guerra arancelaria y todavía no se conocen detalles concretos de los acuerdos alcanzados en estas conversaciones. La agencia oficial de noticias china Xinhua confirmó el comienzo del encuentro en un escueto comunicado. Fuentes de la agencia dpa confirmaron el final de lo que acabó convirtiéndose en la primera ronda de un fin de semana de conversaciones. En declaraciones formuladas antes del viaje, Bessent ya anticipó que no esperaba lograr un acuerdo en Ginebra. Dijo que espera definir los términos sobre los que conversar. Las discusiones en Ginebra son “un paso positivo y constructivo hacia la reducción de la escalada”, dijo la directora general de la Organización Mundial del Comercio (OMC), Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala. A mediados de abril, Okonjo-Iweala se mostró “muy preocupada” y estimó que incluso si el comercio entre China y Estados Unidos “representa solo alrededor del 3% del comercio mundial de mercancías, un desacoplamiento” de las dos principales economías “podría tener consecuencias considerables”. La presidenta de Suiza, Karin Keller-Sutter, relacionó la elección del papa León XIV con las negociaciones. El viceprimer ministro chino He Lifeng llegó a las negociaciones con el buen dato de que China aumentó un 8,1% sus exportaciones en abril. Esa cifra es cuatro veces superior a la prevista por los analistas. En paralelo las exportaciones a Estados Unidos cayeron casi un 18%. Pese a ello, la secretaria de prensa de la Casa Blanca, Karoline Leavitt, advirtió que Trump “no va a bajar unilateralmente los aranceles a China” y pidió “concesiones”.

title: EU y China anuncian “avances importantes” en negociaciones comerciales tras guerra de aranceles
content: Tanto Estados Unidos como China señalaron avances tras dos días de negociaciones en Ginebra para rebajar tensiones por la guerra comercial que estalló cuando Trump anunció aranceles que golpearon al ...
resumen:
Estados Unidos y China anunciaron “avances sustanciales” tras dos días de negociaciones en Ginebra para rebajar las tensiones entre las dos primeras economías mundiales por la guerra comercial lanzada por el presidente Donald Trump.

El secretario del Tesoro estadounidense, Scott Bessent, declaró que lograron avances sustanciales entre Estados Unidos y China en las importantísimas conversaciones comerciales.

El representante de comercio estadounidense, Jamieson Greer, subrayó que las diferencias entre ambos países no eran “tan grandes como podíamos imaginar”.

El vice primer ministro chino también habló de “avances importantes” en las negociaciones comerciales con Estados Unidos.

Ambos países emitirán un comunicado conjunto el lunes.

La guerra comercial entre Pekín y Washington estalló cuando Trump adoptó una andanada de aranceles que golpearon específicamente a China. El gigante asiático respondió entonces con duras medidas de represalia.

Trump afirmó el sábado que en el primer día de conversaciones a puerta cerrada se había registrado “un gran progreso”.

Las reuniones se desarrollaron en la lujosa residencia del Representante Permanente de Suiza ante la ONU en la capital del país.

El diálogo es la reunión de más alto nivel entre las dos mayores economías del mundo desde el regreso a la Casa Blanca de Trump, quien adoptó una ofensiva arancelaria que defendió como una forma de contrarrestar prácticas que considera injustas y defender empleos en Estados Unidos.

Desde el inicio de este año, los aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos a China ascienden al 145 %, y los gravámenes acumulados para ciertos productos alcanzan la asombrosa cifra del 245 %.

En respuesta, China impuso aranceles del 125 % a los productos estadounidenses y como resultado el comercio bilateral entre las dos primeras economías mundiales se estancó.

Antes de las negociaciones, Trump sugirió que podría rebajar los aranceles para el país asiático a un 80 %.

La portavoz de la Casa Blanca, Karoline Leavitt, aclaró después que Estados Unidos no va a reducir los aranceles de forma unilateral y agregó que China también deberá hacer concesiones.

El secretario del Tesoro afirmó que las negociaciones estaban centradas en rebajar las tensiones y no en buscar un “gran acuerdo comercial”.

China, a su vez, insistió en que Estados Unidos debía bajar los aranceles primero.

Gary Hufbauer, investigador principal no residente del Peterson Institute for International Economics (PIIE), explicó que el mero hecho de que se celebren conversaciones “es una buena noticia para las empresas y para los mercados financieros”.

El vice primer ministro chino llegó a las negociaciones con la tranquilidad de que las exportaciones chinas subieron en abril un 8.1%.

Para Hufbauer, entre algunos miembros más moderados del gobierno de Trump, como Bessent y el secretario de Comercio de Estados Unidos, Howard Lutnick, “existe la conciencia de que China está mejor preparada que Estados Unidos para hacer frente a esta guerra comercial”.

title: Donald Trump y Reino Unido firman acuerdo comercial histórico: ¿el inicio de una nueva era económica?

resumen: Estados Unidos y China cerraron el domingo 11 de mayo de 2025 dos días de negociaciones sobre aranceles en Ginebra. El presidente Donald Trump aseguró que se negociaba un «reinicio total» de las relaciones. El secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent, habló de «progreso sustancial». El viceprimer ministro He Linfeng habló de contactos profundos y constructivos, y de un acuerdo para establecer un mecanismo de consulta económico-comercial. El representante de Comercio estadounidense, Jamieson Greer, sostuvo que se puede confiar en que el acuerdo alcanzado con China ayudará a su país a resolver el déficit comercial, que el Gobierno de Trump ha cifrado en 1,2 billones de dólares. India y Pakistán, ambos con armas nucleares, han evitado la guerra a gran escala desde 1971. La estabilidad nuclear en la región se basa en la disuasión, donde ambos países creen que un ataque nuclear del otro resultaría en una represalia inaceptable.

La estrategia de Pakistán se centra en la "disuasión creíble mínima", buscando armas nucleares para disuadir la agresión india. Pakistán ha desarrollado armas nucleares de corto alcance y desplegado armas nucleares en tierra, mar y aire.

La estrategia de India es la "disuasión creíble", con un arsenal nuclear más grande y una "doctrina de represalia nuclear" que implica un ataque nuclear masivo para infligir daños inaceptables. India tiene la "tríada nuclear" (capacidad de lanzar armas nucleares desde tierra, mar y aire).

Las tensiones entre India y Pakistán han aumentado en los últimos años, especialmente después de los ataques terroristas en India atribuidos a grupos con sede en Pakistán. La crisis de Kargil en 1999 y el ataque a la asamblea estatal de Jammu y Cachemira en 2001-2002 son ejemplos de escaladas.

La comunidad internacional ha desempeñado un papel en la gestión de las crisis, pero la estabilidad nuclear en el sur de Asia sigue siendo precaria.

title: TERRY SCHILLING: Why Are Senate RINOs Still Protecting China’s Dirty Practices?
content: President Trump has declared Liberation Day, launching a bold new round of tariffs to restore American industry, confront the Chinese Communist ...
resumen: President Trump has declared Liberation Day, launching a new round of tariffs to restore American industry, confront the Chinese Communist Party, and end decades of globalist betrayal. A group of Senate Republicans is trying to stop him. Some Senate Republicans were already backing legislation to strip President Trump of the authority to impose tariffs. This is what RINO politics looks like; deference to Wall Street over Main Street, reflexive globalism over American sovereignty. Trump’s first term’s economic policies sparked a manufacturing revival. Now he’s going further with Liberation Day, cutting off our dependence on countries that hate us, and punishing those that have gamed the system for decades. Members of Congress should be working with the President to ensure lasting victories in the trade war. No country has abused the system more than China. One of their biggest advantages is pollution as a trade weapon. President Trump has called these countries “filthy pollution havens”. The Foreign Pollution Fee Act would impose a fee on imports from high-polluting countries like China, holding them accountable for their environmental abuses and protecting American manufacturers. It would restore fairness to global markets, give U.S. industry a real chance to compete, and ensure that environmental responsibility is rewarded. It would lock in the gains of Trump’s trade agenda. This is the kind of trade policy we should have had all along. The Republican Party is being tested. Even the harshest critics of tariffs admit that environmental dumping by countries like China is real, persistent, and economically distorting. The RINOs trying to stop him are siding with China, not America. Terry Schilling is the president of the American Principles Project.

title: US and China hail 'constructive' Geneva trade talks
content: The US and China end high-stakes trade talks on a positive note, with US officials touting a "deal" to reduce the US trade deficit while Chinese officials said the sides had reached an "important ...
resumen:
Geneva talks between China and the US have been hailed as "substantial progress" between the two nations.

US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer touted the talks with China as a success.

Chinese officials said the sides had reached "important consensus" and agreed to launch another new economic dialogue forum.

Neither side released details after they wrapped up two days of talks on Sunday in Switzerland.

Chinese Vice-Premier He Lifeng said a joint statement would be released in Geneva on Monday.

Vice-Commerce Minister Li Chenggang said it would contain "good news for the world".

US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer described "substantial progress" and also said details would be announced on Monday.

Neither side mentioned any agreement to cut US tariffs of 145 per cent on Chinese goods and China's 125 per cent tariffs on US goods.

Mr Greer and Mr Bessent took no questions from reporters.

Mr Greer described the Geneva meetings' conclusion as "a deal we struck with our Chinese partners" that would help reduce the $US1.2 trillion ($1.9 trillion) US global goods trade deficit.

The US trade chief called Mr He, Mr Li and Vice-Finance Minister Liao Min "tough negotiators".

Mr He, speaking to reporters at China's mission to the World Trade Organization, described the talks as "candid, in-depth and constructive" on issues of concern to both countries.

The meeting achieved substantial progress, and reached important consensus.

He also met with WTO Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, who said she was "pleased with the positive outcome" of the talks and urged the two countries to build on momentum to mitigate trade tensions.

The US and China agreed to establish a new consultation mechanism for trade and economic issues, with relevant details to be finalised as soon as possible, Mr He added.

The meeting was the first face-to-face interaction between senior US and Chinese economic officials since Mr Trump took office and launched a global tariff blitz, declaring a national emergency over the US fentanyl crisis and imposing a 20 per cent tariff on Chinese goods in February.

Mr Trump followed with a 34 per cent "reciprocal" duty on Chinese imports in April, and subsequent rounds pushed the rates into triple digits, bringing nearly $US600 billion ($935 billion) in two-way trade to a standstill.

Mr Trump said on Friday that an 80 per cent tariff on Chinese goods "seems right", suggesting for the first time a specific reduction target.

Mr Greer said there was a lot of groundwork done before the Geneva meetings on Saturday and Sunday, and that the result would address the national emergency that Mr Trump declared over growing US trade deficits.

A White House press release that simply repeated Mr Bessent's and Mr Greer's brief comments with no details ran the headline: "US announces China trade deal in Geneva."

White House economic adviser Kevin Hassett said the Chinese were "very, very eager" to engage in discussions and rebalance trade relations with the US.

title: Taiwán quiere seguir su cooperación militar e industrial con EEUU pese a aranceles
content: Taiwán quiere continuar fortaleciendo su cooperación militar e industrial con Estados Unidos a pesar de la guerra comercial lanzada por la administración de Donald Trump, dijo el domingo un funcionari ...
resumen:
Taiwán quiere continuar fortaleciendo su cooperación militar e industrial con Estados Unidos a pesar de la guerra comercial lanzada por la administración de Donald Trump.

El gobierno estadounidense ha impuesto aranceles a todos a sus socios comerciales. A Taiwán se le habían aplicado tarifas del 32 % con la excepción de los semiconductores, en los que esa isla es líder, antes de que Trump las suspendiera a mediados de abril por tres meses.

Bajo presión, el gigante taiwanés de esos sofisticados chips TSMC reveló recientemente un proyecto de inversión por 100.000 millones de dólares adicionales en Estados Unidos.

"Vimos al mundo entero manifestar su preocupación sobre el asunto de los aranceles y nuestro presidente, Lai Ching-te, ya se ha reunido con los directivos de grandes empresas taiwanesas", dijo Kung Ming-hsin, miembro del gobierno de Taiwán durante una visita a Washington para participar en una cumbre de inversionistas.

Pese a esta situación de incertidumbre "buscamos desarrollar nuestra cooperación con Estados Unidos", en especial en el campo militar, agregó Kung.

"Podemos hacer investigación y desarrollo conjunto en el campo de los drones, por ejemplo. Estados Unidos tiene tecnologías avanzadas y Taiwán es muy bueno para producir masivamente este tipo de tecnología", subrayó.

Kung encabeza en Washington una comitiva de 183 delegados de Taiwán, el contingente extranjero más grande en el evento de inversiones SelectUSA, que representan 138 empresas y emprendimientos taiwaneses que buscan explotar las oportunidades de inversión y cooperación en Estados Unidos.

En 2024, Taiwán fue el séptimo socio comercial más importante para Estados Unidos, con 157.900 millones de dólares, según Kung.

title: Brian Wong, estratega geopolítico: "A corto plazo China sufrirá más por los aranceles que EEUU, pero a largo plazo los agradecerá"
content: El estratega y filósofo augura una 'guerra civil' entre las distintas facciones dentro de la Administración Trump por su posición respecto de China y advierte de que el mandatario está acabando con la ...
resumen:
Brian Wong, estratega geopolítico, afirma que a corto plazo China sufrirá más por los aranceles que EEUU, pero a largo plazo los agradecerá.

Wong, graduado en Filosofía, Economía y Política por la Universidad de Oxford y doctorando en Filosofía Política por la misma universidad, fue entrevistado en la redacción de 20minutos.

Wong opina que Trump es un síntoma, no la causa de los males que aquejan a Estados Unidos.

Wong cree que hay razones sistémicas por las que las relaciones entre Estados Unidos y China seguirán en tensión.

Wong señala que Pekín está aprendiendo a ser una potencia regional fuerte e importante y que debe aprender a posicionarse de manera adecuada en relación con los demás actores del mapa mundial.

Wong menciona que hay dos probabilidades de tres de que el mandato de Trump y su política hacia China queden definidos por una guerra civil entre facciones rivales dentro de su propia administración: los halcones acérrimos, los halcones pragmáticos y moderados, los empresarios, los aislacionistas económicos y los tecnócratas.

Wong opina que a corto plazo China va a sufrir más por los aranceles, pero a largo plazo, China estará agradecida.

Wong explica que durante la última década los líderes chinos se han dado cuenta de la necesidad de alejarse de la producción excesiva de infraestructuras y de dejar de depender de poderosos oligopolios tecnológicos, invirtiendo en una fabricación avanzada y en I+D.

Wong cree que Estados Unidos va a salir gravemente perjudicado a largo plazo porque muchos países están llegando a dos conclusiones: cuanto más se prolongue la negociación arancelaria, más ventaja tendrán frente a EEUU; y que el comercio se basa en la confianza, algo que está en duda con Trump.

Wong menciona que los países necesitan acceso a las tierras raras para hacer frente a los retos que se avecinan, y que la posesión de estos metales es una baza muy importante.

Wong sugiere que la Unión Europea debería empezar a reforzar la resiliencia de la cadena de suministro en lo que respecta a las tierras raras, trabajando con socios en África y Latinoamérica.

Wong señala que Groenlandia tiene un volumen entre ocho y diez veces superior al de los minerales disponibles en Ucrania.

Wong sugiere que China podría ofrecer materias primas y minerales críticos a Europa como muestra de sinceridad.

title: Ventaja y ganancia ante la adversidad (OPINION)
content: Es sabido por todos que hoy el mundo se enfrenta a muchos desafíos, amenazas, debilidades económicas y enfermedades que requieren de respuestas rápidas, adecuadas, oportunas y resilientes, que no perm ...
resumen:
El autor es administrador financiero y contralor general de la República, reside en Santo Domingo.

El mundo se enfrenta a desafíos, amenazas, debilidades económicas y enfermedades que requieren respuestas rápidas y resilientes.

Las autoridades dominicanas han sido diligentes, proactivas, prudentes, vigilantes y planificadoras ante los acontecimientos mundiales, incluyendo los aumentos de aranceles impuestos por la administración Trump.

Las autoridades monetarias y fiscales dominicanas han dado respuesta adecuada y oportuna a la incertidumbre y turbulencia económica.

El Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI) publicó un informe advirtiendo que el sistema económico internacional se está reseteando.

El FMI recomienda que en un contexto de tensiones comerciales e incertidumbre, el camino a seguir estará definido por cómo se afrontan las dificultades y se aprovechan las oportunidades.

El FMI redujo la proyección de crecimiento de la economía mundial a 2,8% en 2025 y 3% en 2026, pero para la República Dominicana se espera un crecimiento de 4% en ambos años.

La República Dominicana está entre los países con mejores condiciones para ganar ante la incertidumbre debido al aumento de los aranceles, por los menores aranceles aplicados, el desvío de inversiones y los acuerdos bilaterales con Estados Unidos.

El Banco Mundial y el Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI) han destacado la resiliencia de la República Dominicana, proyectando un crecimiento económico del 4% en 2025 y 4.8% para 2026.

El FMI apunta como crucial, emprender oportunamente una consolidación fiscal para recomponer los márgenes de maniobras.

La tasa del dólar respecto al peso se ha estabilizado en RD$59.83 por US$1.00, apreciándose la moneda dominicana en 2.3% y 2.5% en comparación con el cierre del año 2024.

Durante el primer trimestre de 2025 la economía dominicana creció 2.7%, cayendo un 1.80% respecto a igual periodo 2024, pero en abril creció 4.5%.

El barril de petróleo ha fluctuado a la baja entre US$55.00 a US$58.00 dólares el barril.

La institución emisora dominicana ha transmitido confianza, pero alerta sobre los impactos de una posible desaceleración de la actividad económica de Estados Unidos.

El país es un destino atrayente para el nearshoring.

Para 2025 se proyectan ingresos por inversión de US$4,700 millones.

El Banco Central de la República Dominicana cuenta con reservas internacionales de 14,751 millones de dólares al cierre de marzo, equivalente a 11.7% del PIB y más de cinco meses de importaciones.

La variación del Índice de Precio al Consumidor (IPC) del mes de abril 2025 fue de 0.03%, resultando en una inflación interanual de 3.71%, manteniéndose por 17 meses consecutivos entre el límite inferior y el centro del rango meta de 4.0% +- 1.0%.

El turismo registró en el primer cuatrimestre unos 4.3 millones de turistas, un aumento de 17% en comparación con el mismo periodo del año 2023, aportando unos US$3,533 millones o casi US$4,000 millones aproximadamente enero-abril 2025.

title: How President Donald Trump Could Support Working Class Voters
content: Lynn Forester de Rothschild argues that a pro-growth and pro-worker agenda is necessary to support working class Americans.
resumen:
President Donald Trump increased his support among voters without a college degree from around 50% in 2020 to 56% in 2024, with more than 50 million working class people voting for Donald Trump in 2024.

The author offers four recommendations for President Trump to more meaningfully demonstrate his commitment to the working people:

1.  Stop Collecting Tax from the Lowest Paid Workers: The United States begins to collect tax from working families starting at an annual income of only $21,900 for a head of household, even though the national poverty level for a family of four is $32,150. The Trump Administration should legislate so that there is a zero federal tax rate for families who earn less than the federal poverty level.
2.  Provide Workers the Skills they Need: Portable training accounts, which follow workers across jobs, would provide continuity in a dynamic economy. The author urges President Trump to invest in education and skills training.
3.  Give Workers an Investment Where they Work: By reforming current regulatory and litigation risks around Employee Stock Ownership Plans (ESOPs), the administration can unlock share ownership opportunities for workers—not only in private firms but also public companies.
4.  Embrace worker-centric AI: The World Economic Forum’s Future of Jobs Report highlights opportunities in sectors such as agriculture, food processing, nursing, and software development. The White House, with Vice President JD Vance’s experience in tech, should seize this moment to build a national AI strategy that does not leave the workers behind. More than 250 CEOs signed an open letter calling for computer science and AI to become graduation requirements nationwide across the US. They highlight research showing a single AI course raises wages 8% across all students. The letter argues universal AI could unlock $660 billion in annual economic value and notes only 12 states currently mandate the subject.

title: La extorsión de Trump a Latinoamérica: lo que ha conseguido el republicano de la región con sus amenazas
content: La táctica principal de intimidación usada por el magnate han sido los aranceles, con los que ha arrancado concesiones de países aliados como México o Colombia ...
resumen:
Donald Trump ha adoptado el chantaje como política exterior y comercial, especialmente hacia América Latina. Su táctica principal de intimidación han sido los aranceles, con los que ha arrancado concesiones de países aliados como México o Colombia.

Con tres meses en el cargo, Trump ha conseguido que el Gobierno de Claudia Sheinbaum militarice la frontera mexicana con Estados Unidos y que Colombia, Costa Rica y Panamá accedan a que las autoridades migratorias estadounidenses deporten a migrantes a sus territorios.

México, siendo el principal socio comercial de Estados Unidos, fue el principal blanco de las amenazas arancelarias de Trump. En su segunda semana de vuelta en la Casa Blanca anunció la imposición de aranceles del 25% a las importaciones de México a partir del 4 de febrero, justificando que el país vecino no estaba haciendo lo suficiente para frenar el tráfico de fentanilo y migrantes. El Gobierno de Sheinbaum aceptó reforzar la frontera y desplegar 10.000 militares. Trump impuso los aranceles del 25%, que continúan en vigor, aunque con un impacto muy disminuido. El Gobierno mexicano ha cedido a la coacción de Trump en materia migratoria y de seguridad, con la entrega de 29 capos del narcotráfico a Estados Unidos.

En el caso de Colombia, Trump amenazó con aranceles al Gobierno de Gustavo Petro cuando este se negó a aceptar vuelos con deportados. Trump reaccionó diciendo que golpearía a Colombia con aranceles del 25%, así como con sanciones financieras y bancarias, y suspendió los visados para funcionarios colombianos. Petro cedió a las demandas, incluyendo la aceptación de deportados. Colombia fue gravada con la tarifa mínima del 10% en abril.

Costa Rica y Panamá han aceptado recibir vuelos de deportados. Ambos países fueron gravados con la tarifa mínima del 10% en abril. Panamá ha tenido que ceder en otras cosas para aplacar a Trump, como permitir que la empresa estadounidense BlackRock comprara puertos del país.

Las tácticas de coacción de Trump contra el régimen de Nicolás Maduro en Venezuela son diversas, incluyendo aranceles, amenazas de sanciones y golpes al sector petrolero. Después de que Washington retirara licencias a Chevron, Caracas informó que no aceptaría deportaciones, lo que llevó a Trump a amenazar con nuevas sanciones. Maduro acordó reanudar los vuelos. El Gobierno de Trump anunció que impondría aranceles del 25% a todos los países que importen petróleo y gas venezolano y prorrogó la salida de Chevron.

El Salvador ha tenido una relación beneficiosa con Trump y Nayib Bukele. Bukele acepta y encarcela a migrantes deportados por Estados Unidos, recibiendo dinero y la convalidación de su modelo carcelario. El Salvador recibirá de vuelta a por lo menos nueve pandilleros clave de la MS-13. Bukele ofreció un descuento del 50 % en la tarifa por recibir migrantes deportados en su megaprisión.

title: From US dollar hegemony to opportunity for euro
content: While internationalisation does carry risks, the eurozone is well-positioned to mitigate them. For example, the eurozone’s macro-prudential policy frameworks, which are much stronger than those in the ...
resumen: International monetary and financial systems may not be immutable. The upheaval spurred by US President Donald Trump’s trade and tariff war is remarkable and difficult to decipher. Charles P. Kindleberger’s theory of hegemonic stability states that an open and stable international system depends on a dominant world power. In the nineteenth century, that power was Great Britain. World War I took its toll on Britain, which by the 1930s no longer had sufficient resources to underpin the international monetary system. The United States was an ascending power but was not yet ready to fill Britain’s shoes. This “Kindleberger gap” coincided with the Great Depression and the escalating political turmoil that culminated in World War II. In 1944, delegates from 44 countries met in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, where they orchestrated a smooth transition between the old and the new hegemons. The United States accounted for 35% of world gross domestic product (GDP) at the time. The US dollar has retained its dominance as a reserve asset, invoicing currency, and anchor for fixed exchange rates. The US Federal Reserve’s policy decisions and the US economy’s performance still shape the global financial cycle. We seem to be approaching a new “Kindleberger gap”. The existing hegemon appears to be self-destructing, as it refuses to supply global public goods, and there is no clear candidate to fill its shoes. The European Union (EU) is not prepared to take up the mantle, and China is not even integrated into global financial markets. The Trump administration appears convinced that global demand for US dollar assets is a burden. If a currency is to serve an international role, the country issuing it generally needs to enjoy economic pre-eminence and occupy a central position in global trade. These qualities depend on innovative capabilities and growth potential, with military power and geopolitical alliances also playing a role. None of this is possible without an open economy and high-quality, stable institutions. The United States under Trump is rapidly eroding trust in the US dollar. In early April, Trump announced ultra-high tariffs on goods from dozens of countries running bilateral trade surpluses. US Treasury yields rose, the US stock market fell, and the US dollar depreciated. This economic and financial distress creates an opportunity for the eurozone to capture some of the exorbitant privilege long enjoyed by the United States. This includes cheaper capital for eurozone governments and businesses, which could support fiscal sustainability, and easier refinancing during times of crises. It also includes increased geopolitical clout. The eurozone is well-positioned to mitigate risks. The eurozone’s macro-prudential policy frameworks are much stronger than those in the United States. The eurozone must deepen its single market in goods and services and strengthen its trade relationships. Europe could consider starting to invoice climate-friendly products in euros. The eurozone should also commit to completing the banking union and the savings and investment union. Efforts should be made to deliver a true eurozone-wide safe asset. Joint debt issuance for emergency defence spending could be a good starting point. The bloc must increase the sovereignty of its own payments systems. This would probably rely on a central bank digital currency, complemented with a robust payment system. The European Central Bank’s function as lender of last resort must be carefully structured.
